Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 1. Operation code field is present in :
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: Machine language instruction format has one or more fields. The first one is the operation code field.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 2. A machine language instruction format consists of
options: c) Operation code field & operand field
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: Machine language instruction format has both the fields.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 3. The length of the one-byte instruction is
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: This format is only one byte long.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 4. The instruction format ‘register to register’ has a length of
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: This format is 2 bytes long.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 5. The R/M field in a machine instruction format specifies
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: The LSBs(least significant bits) from 0 to 3 represent R/M field that specifies another register or memory location i.e. the other operand.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 6. In a machine instruction format, S-bit is the
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: The S-bit known as sign extension bit is used along with W-bit to show the type of operation.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 7. The bit which is used by the ‘REP’ instruction is
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: The Z-bit is used by the REP instruction to control the loop.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 8. If a W-bit value is ‘1’ then the operand is of
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: If W-bit is ‘1’ then the operand is of 16-bits, and if it is ‘0’ then the operand is of 8-bits.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 9. The instructions which after execution transfer control to the next instruction in the sequence are called
options: c) Sequential control flow & control transfer instructions
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: The sequential control flow instructions follow sequence order in their execution.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 10. The instructions that transfer the control to some predefined address or the address specified in the instruction are called as
options: c) sequential control flow & control transfer instructions
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: The control transfer instructions transfer control to the specified address.

Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.question: 11. The instruction “JUMP” belongs to
Machine-Language-Instruction-Formats.explaination: Explanation: The JUMP instruction transfers the control to the address located in the instruction.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 1. The instruction, MOV AX, 0005H belongs to the address mode
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: In Immediate addressing mode, immediate data is a part of instruction and appears in the form of successive byte or bytes.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 2. The instruction, MOV AX, 1234H is an example of
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: Since immediate data is present in the instruction.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 3. The instruction, MOV AX, [2500H] is an example of
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: Since the address is directly specified in the instruction as a part of it.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 4. If the data is present in a register and it is referred using the particular register, then it is
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: Since register is used to refer the address.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 5. The instruction, MOV AX,[BX] is an example of
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: Since the register used to refer to the address is accessed indirectly.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 6. If the offset of the operand is stored in one of the index registers, then it is
options: b) relative based indexed addressing mode
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: In the indexed addressing mode, the offset of an operand is stored and in the rest of them, address is stored.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 7. The addressing mode that is used in unconditional branch instructions is
options: c) intrasegment direct and indirect addressing mode
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: In intrasegment indirect mode, the branch address is found as the content of a register or a memory location.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 8. If the location to which the control is to be transferred lies in a different segment other than the current one, then the mode is called
options: d) intersegment direct and indirect mode
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: In intersegment mode, the control to be transferred lies in a different segment.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 9. The instruction, JMP 5000H:2000H;
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: Since in intersegment direct mode, the address to which the control is to be transferred is in a different segment.

Addressing-Modes-of-8086.question: 10. The contents of a base register are added to the contents of index register in
options: c) relative based indexed addressing mode
d) based indexed and relative based indexed addressing mode
Addressing-Modes-of-8086.explaination: Explanation: The effective address is formed by adding the contents of both base and index registers to a default segment.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 1. The instruction that is used to transfer the data from source operand to destination operand is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: These instructions are used to copy and transfer the instructions.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 2. Which of the following is not a data copy/transfer instruction?
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: DAS (Decimal Adjust after Subtraction) is an arithmetic instruction.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 3. The instructions that involve various string manipulation operations are
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The string instructions perform operations on strings such as load, move, scan, compare etc.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 4. Which of the following instruction is not valid?
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Both the source and destination operands cannot be memory locations except for string instructions.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 5. In PUSH instruction, after each execution of the instruction, the stack pointer is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The actual current stack-top is always occupied by the previously pushed data. So, the push operation decrements SP by 2 and then stores the two bytes contents of the operand onto the stack.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 6. The instruction that pushes the contents of the specified register/memory location on to the stack is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Since PUSH operation transfers data to stack from a register or memory location.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 7. In POP instruction, after each execution of the instruction, the stack pointer is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The actual current stack top is poped into the specific operand as the contents of stack top memory is stored in AL&SP and further contents of the memory location pointed to by SP are copied to AH & SP.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 8. The instructions that are used for reading an input port and writing an output port respectively are
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The address of the input/output port may be specified directly or indirectly.              Example for input port: IN AX, DX; This instruction reads data from a 16-bit port whose address is in DX and stores it in AX              Example for output port: OUT 03H, AL; This sends data available in AL to a port whose address is 03H.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 9. The instruction that is used for finding out the codes in case of code conversion problems is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The translate(XLAT) instruction is used to find codes.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 10. The instruction that loads effective address formed by destination operand into the specified source register is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The instruction, LEA loads effective address and is more useful for assembly language rather than for machine language.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 11. The instruction that loads the AH register with the lower byte of the flag register is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The instruction LAHF(Load AH from a lower byte of Flag) may be used to observe the status of all the condition code flags(except overflow flag) at a time.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 12. The instruction that pushes the flag register on to the stack is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The instruction PUSHF(push flags to stack) pushes the flag register on to the stack.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 13. The instruction that loads the flag register completely from the word contents of the memory location is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: POPF is pop flags to stack.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 14. The instruction that adds immediate data/contents of the memory location specified in an instruction/register to the contents of another register/memory location is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: ADD instruction adds the data.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.question: 15. The instruction that supports addition when carry exists is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: ADC(Add with Carry) instruction performs the same operation as ADD operation, but adds the carry flag bit to the result.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 1. The instruction, “INC” increases the contents of the specified register or memory location by
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: This instruction adds 1 to the contents of the operand and so increments by 1.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 2. The instruction that subtracts 1 from the contents of the specified register/memory location is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The DEC instruction decrements the contents of a specified register/memory location by 1.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 3. The instruction that enables subtraction with borrow is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The SBB instruction subtracts the source operand and the borrow flag from the destination operand.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 4. The flag that acts as Borrow flag in the instruction, SBB is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If borrow exists in the subtraction operation performed then carry flag is set.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 5. In general, the source operand of an instruction can be
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The source operand is the element which is data or data stored memory location on which operation is performed.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 6. In general, the destination operand of an instruction can be
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: Since the destination should be able to store the data, immediate data cannot be considered as a destination operand.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 7. The instruction, CMP to compare source and destination operands it performs
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: For comparison, the instruction CMP subtracts source operand from destination operand.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 8. During comparison operation, the result of comparing or subtraction is stored in
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The result of subtraction operation is not stored anywhere during a comparison.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 9. The instruction that converts the result in an unpacked decimal digits is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: All the ASCII adjust instructions give result in unpacked decimal form and so are called as “Unpacked BCD arithmetic instructions”.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 10. Which of the following is a mnemonic?
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: AAA is a mnemonic. It doesn’t have either a source or destination operand.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 11. The instruction in which adjustment is made before performing the operation is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The AAD instruction converts two unpacked BCD digits in AH and AL to the equivalent binary number in AL. This adjustment must be made before dividing the two unpacked BCD digits.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 12. The expansion of DAA is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: This instruction performs conversion operation.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 13. The instruction that is used to convert the result of the addition of two packed BCD numbers to a valid BCD number is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: In this conversion, the result has to be only in AL.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.question: 14. The ROR instruction rotates the contents of the destination operand to
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: ROR stands for Rotate Right without carry. so, the instruction rotates right.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 1. The mnemonic that is placed before the arithmetic operation is performed is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: The AAD instruction converts two unpacked BCD digits in AH and AL to the equivalent binary number in AL.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 2. The Carry flag is undefined after performing the operation
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: Since the operation, AAD is performed before division operation is performed, the carry flag, auxiliary flag and overflow flag are undefined.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 3. The instruction that performs logical AND operation and the result of the operation is not available is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: In the TEST instruction, the logical AND operation is performed and the result is not stored but flags are affected.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 4. In the RCL instruction, the contents of the destination operand undergo function as
options: a) carry flag is pushed into LSB & MSB is pushed into the carry flag
b) carry flag is pushed into MSB & LSB is pushed into the carry flag
c) auxiliary flag is pushed into LSB & MSB is pushed into the carry flag
d) parity flag is pushed into MSB & LSB is pushed into the carry flag
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: In RCL(Rotate right through carry), for each operation, the carry flag is pushed into LSB and the MSB of the operand is pushed into carry flag.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 5. The instruction that is used as prefix to an instruction to execute it repeatedly until the CX register becomes zero is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: The instruction to which the REP is prefix, is executed repeatedly until CX register becomes zero. When CX becomes zero, the execution proceeds to the next instruction in sequence.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 6. Match the following
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.code:
A) MOvSB/SW       1) loads AL/AX register by content of a string
B) CMPS           2) moves a string of bytes stored in source to destination
C) SCAS           3) compares two strings of bytes or words whose length is stored in CX register
D) LODS           4) scans a string of bytes or words
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: By using the string instructions, the operations on strings can be performed.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 7. The instructions that are used to call a subroutine from the main program and return to the main program after execution of called function are
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: At each CALL instruction, the IP and CS of the next instruction are pushed onto the stack, before the control is transferred to the procedure. At the end of the procedure, the RET instruction must be executed to retrieve the stored contents of IP & CS registers from a stack.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 8. The instruction that unconditionally transfers the control of execution to the specified address is
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: In this the control transfers to the address specified in the instruction and flags are not affected by this instruction.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 9. Which instruction cannot force the 8086 processor out of ‘halt’ state?
options: c) Both interrupt request and reset
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: Only an interrupt request or Reset will force the 8086 processor to come out of the ‘halt’ state.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 10. NOP instruction introduces
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: NOP is the No operation. It means that the processor performs no operation for the clock cycle and thus there exists a delay.

Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.question: 11. Which of the following is not a machine controlled instruction?
Instruction-Set-of-8086/8088-\u2013-3.explaination: Explanation: Since CLC is a flag manipulation instruction where CLC stands for Clear Carry Flag.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 1. The assembler directives which are the hints using some predefined alphabetical strings are given to
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: These directives help the assembler to correctly understand the assembly language programs to prepare the codes.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 2. The directive used to inform the assembler, the names of the logical segments to be assumed for different segments used in the program is
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: In ALP, each segment is given a name by using the directive ASSUME             SYNTAX: ASSUME segment:segment_name                 Eg: ASSUME CS:Code                 here CS is the Code segment and code is the name assumed to the segment.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.code:
a) DB          1) used to direct the assembler to reserve only 10-bytes
   b) DT          2) used to direct the assembler to reserve only 4 words
   c) DW          3) used to direct the assembler to reserve byte or bytes
   d) DQ          4) used to direct the assembler to reserve words
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: These directives are used for allocating memory locations in the available memory.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 4. The directive that marks the end of an assembly language program is
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: The directive END is used to denote the completion of the program.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 5. The directive that marks the end of a logical segment is
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: The directive ENDS is used to end a segment where as the directive END is used to end the program.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 6. The directive that updates the location counter to the next even address while executing a series of instructions is
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: The directive updates location counter to next even address if the current location counter contents are not even.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 7. The directive that directs the assembler to start the memory allotment for a particular segment/block/code from the declared address is
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: If an ORG is written then the assembler initiates the location counter to keep the track of allotted address for the module as mentioned in the directive.If the directive is not present, then the location counter is initialized to 0000H.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 8. The directive that marks the starting of the logical segment is
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: The directive SEGMENT indicates the beginning of the segment.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 9. The recurrence of the numerical values or constants in a program code is reduced by
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: In this, the recurring/repeating value is assigned with a label. The label is placed instead of the numerical value in the entire program code.

Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.question: 10. The labels or constants that can be used by any module in the program is possible when they are declared as
Assembler-Directives-and-Operators.explaination: Explanation: The labels, constants, variables, procedures declared as GLOBAL can be used by any module in the program.

Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.question: 1. The logic required for implementing a program can be expressed in terms of
Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.explaination: Explanation: The logic required for implementing a program must be visualized clearly which is possible by flowchart and algorithm.

Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.question: 2. The operands, source and destination in an instruction cannot be
Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.explaination: Explanation: Only one memory operand can be specified in one instruction.

Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.question: 3. The instruction that is not possible among the following is
Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.explaination: Explanation: 8-bit or 16-bit operand cannot be used as a destination operand.

Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.question: 4. The instruction that is not possible among the following is
Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.explaination: Explanation: Both the operands cannot be memory operands.

Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.question: 5. Both the operands source and destination of an instruction cannot be
Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.explaination: Explanation: Since destination operand should not be immediate data.

Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.question: 6. The registers that cannot be used as operands for arithmetic and logical instructions are
Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.explaination: Explanation: Segment registers are not allowed as operands for arithmetic and logical instructions.

Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.question: 7. The operands of an instruction cannot be
options: b) memory operands and immediate operands
Do\u2019s-and-Don\u2019ts-While-Using-In.explaination: Explanation: Both the operands should not be immediate operands and memory operands.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 1. The disadvantage of machine level programming is
options: b) chances of error are more
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: The machine level programming is complicated.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 2. The coded object modules of the program to be assembled are present in
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: .OBJ file is created with same name as source file and extension .OBJ. It contains the coded object modules of the program to be assembled.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 3. The advantages of assembly level programming are
options: a) flexibility of programming is more
b) chances of error are less
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: The assembly level programming is more advantageous than the machine level programming.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 4. The extension that is essential for every assembly level program is
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: All the files should have the extension, .ASM.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 5. The directory that is under work must have the files that are related to
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: Before starting the process of entering a small program on PC, ensure that all the files namely Norton’s editor, assembler, linker and debugger are available in the same directory in which work is been done.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 6. The listing file is identified by
options: c) source file name and an extension .LSF
d) source file name and an extension .LST
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: The listing file is automatically generated in the assembly process and is identified by the entered or source file name and an extension .LST.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 7. The extension file that is must for a file to be accepted by the LINK as a valid object file is
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: The .OBJ extension is a must for a file to be accepted by the LINK as a valid object file.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 8. The listing file contains
options: a) total offset map of a source file
c) memory allotments for different labels
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: The listing file contains total offset map of source file including labels, offset addresses, opcodes, memory allotments for different directives and labels and relocation information.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 9. DEBUG.COM facilitates the
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: DEBUG.COM is a DOS utility that facilitates the debugging and trouble shooting.

Programming-With-An-Assembler.question: 10. DEBUG is able to troubleshoot only
Programming-With-An-Assembler.explaination: Explanation: The DEBUG may be used either to debug a source program or to observe the results of execution of an .EXE file.

Stack.question: 1. The Stack follows the sequence
Stack.explaination: Explanation: The stack follows last-in-first-out sequence.

Stack.question: 2. If the processor is executing the main program that calls a subroutine, then after executing the main program up to the CALL instruction, the control will be transferred to
Stack.explaination: Explanation: Since subroutine is called, to start the execution of the subroutine, the control is transferred to the subroutine address.

Stack.question: 3. The stack is useful for
options: a) storing the register status of the processor
c) storing contents of registers temporarily inside the CPU
Stack.explaination: Explanation: Stack is used for temporary storage of contents of registers and memory locations, status of registers.

Stack.question: 4. The Stack is accessed using
Stack.explaination: Explanation: The stack is accessed using a pointer that is implemented using SP and SS registers.

Stack.question: 5. As the storing of data words onto the stack is increased, the stack pointer is
Stack.explaination: Explanation: The data is stored from top address of the stack and is decremented by 2.

Stack.question: 6. While retrieving data from the stack, the stack pointer is
Stack.explaination: Explanation: The data in the stack, may again be transferred back from a stack to register. At that time, the stack pointer is incremented by 2.

Stack.question: 7. The process of storing the data in the stack is called ……… the stack.
Stack.explaination: Explanation: The data is pushed into the stack while loading the stack.

Stack.question: 8. The reverse process of transferring the data back from the stack to the CPU register is known as
Stack.explaination: Explanation: The data retrieved from stack is called popping off.

Stack.question: 9. The books arranged one on the other on a table is an example of
Stack.explaination: Explanation: If the books are arranged one on the other, then the book that is placed last will be the first out.

Stack.question: 10. The PID temperature controller using 8086 has
options: b) data flow and uses queue
d) sequential flow and uses stack
Stack.explaination: Explanation: Since PID temperature controller has steps that need to be sequentially executed such as sampling the output, conversion of a signal with ADC, finding errors, deriving control signals and applying the control signal to control flow of energy.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 1. The stack pointer register contains
options: a) address of the stack segment
b) pointer address of the stack segment
c) offset of address of stack segment
d) data present in the stack segment
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The stack pointer register contains the offset of the address of the stack segment.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 2. The stack segment register contains
options: a) address of the stack segment
b) base address of the stack segment
c) pointer address of the stack segment
d) data in the stack segment
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The stack segment register contains base address of the stack segment in the memory. The stack pointer register (sP) and stack segment register (SS) together address the stack-top.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 3. PUSH operation
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: Each PUSH operation decrements the SP ( Stack Pointer) register.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 4. POP operation
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: Each POP operation increments the SP ( Stack Pointer) register.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 5. The register or memory location that is pushed into the stack at the end must be
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The data can be retrieved by POP operation and as in stack, the data that is pushed at the end must be popped off first.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 6. In the instruction, ASSUME CS : CODE, DS : DATA, SS : STACK
options: the ASSUME directive directs to the assembler the
a) address of the stack segment
b) pointer address of the stack segment
c) name of the stack segment
d) name of the stack, code and data segments
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The directive ASSUME facilitates to name the segments with the desired name that is not a mnemonic or keyword.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 7. When a stack segment is initialised then
options: a) SS and SP are initialised
d) SS and SP need not be initialised
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: Though the Stack segment is initialised, the SS and SP pointers must be initialised.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 8. The number of PUSH instructions and POP instructions in a subroutine must be
options: a) PUSH instructions must be greater than POP instructions
b) POP instructions must be greater than PUSH instructions
d) Instructions may be any kind
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The number of PUSH instructions must be equal to the number of POP instructions.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 9. 8086 does not support
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The 8086 microprocessor does not support direct BCD packed operations.

Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.question: 10. For 8086 microprocessor, the stack segment may have a memory block of a maximum of
Stack-Structure-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: In 8086 microprocessor, the memory segments each have a memory of 64K bytes.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 1. While CPU is executing a program, an interrupt exists then it
options: a) follows the next instruction in the program
b) jumps to instruction in other registers
c) breaks the normal sequence of execution of instructions
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: An interrupt function is to break the sequence of operation.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 2. An interrupt breaks the execution of instructions and diverts its execution to
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: An interrupt transfers the control to interrupt service routine (ISR). After executing ISR, the control is transferred back again to the main program.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 3. While executing the main program, if two or more interrupts occur, then the sequence of appearance of interrupts is called
options: d) nested interrupt and interrupt within interrupt
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: If an interrupt occurs while executing a program, and the processor is executing the interrupt, if one more interrupt occurs again, then it is called a nested interrupt.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 4. Whenever a number of devices interrupt a CPU at a time, and if the processor is able to handle them properly, it is said to have
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: The processor if handles more devices as interrupts then it has multiple interrupt processing ability.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 5. NMI stands for
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: NMI is the acronym for nonmaskable interrupt.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 7. If any interrupt request given to an input pin cannot be disabled by any means then the input pin is called
options: c) maskable interrupt and nonmaskable interrupt
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: A nonmaskable interrupt input pin is one which means that any interrupt request at NMI (nonmaskable interrupt) input cannot be masked or disabled by any means.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 8. The INTR interrupt may be
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: the INTR (interrupt request) is maskable or can be disabled.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 9. The Programmable interrupt controller is required to
options: b) handle one or more interrupt requests at a time
c) handle one or more interrupt requests with a delay
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: If more than one interrupt request (INTR) occurs at a time, then an external chip called programmable interrupt controller is required to handle them.

Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.question: 10. The INTR interrupt may be masked using the flag
Interrupts-and-Interrupt-Service-Routine.explaination: Explanation: If a microprocessor wants to serve any interrupt then interrupt flag, IF=1. If interrupt flag, IF=0, then the processor ignores the service.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 1. If an interrupt is generated from outside the processor then it is an
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: If an external device or a signal interrupts the processor from outside then it is an external interrupt.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 2. If the interrupt is generated by the execution of an interrupt instruction then it is
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The internal interrupt is generated internally by the processor circuit or by the execution of an interrupt instruction.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 3. Example of an external interrupt is
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: Since the keyboard is external to the processor, it is an external interrupt.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 4. Example of an internal interrupt is
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: Since the interrupts occur within the processor itself, they are called internal interrupts.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 5. The interrupt request that is independent of IF flag is
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: These requests are independent of IF flag.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 6. The type of the interrupt may be passed to the interrupt structure of CPU from
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: After an interrupt is acknowledged, the CPU computes the vector address from the type of the interrupt that may be passed to the internal structure of the CPU from an interrupt controller in case of external interrupts.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 7. During the execution of an interrupt, the data pushed into the stack is the content of
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: The contents of IP, CS and PSW are pushed into the stack during the execution.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 8. After every response to the single step interrupt the flag that is cleared is
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: If the trap flag is set then the processor enters the single step execution mode. After the execution, the trap flag is cleared.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 9. At the end of ISR, the instruction should be
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: After the execution of the ISR, the control must go to the previous program (maybe main program) which was being executed. To execute it, IRET is placed at the end of ISR.

Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.question: 10. When the CPU executes IRET,
options: a) contents of IP and CS are retrieved
b) the control transfers from ISR to main program
Interrupt-Cycle-of-8086/8088.explaination: Explanation: When the instruction IRET is executed, the contents of flags, IP and CS which were saved at the stack by the CALL instruction are retrieved to the respective registers.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 1. The interrupt for which the processor has the highest priority among all the external interrupts is
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: The Non-Maskable Interrupt input pin has the highest priority among all the external interrupts.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 2. The interrupt for which the processor has highest priority among all the internal interrupts is
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: TRAP is the internal interrupt that has highest priority among all the interrupts except the Divide By Zero (Type 0) exception.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 3. In case of string instructions, the NMI interrupt will be served only after
options: b) execution of some part of the string
d) the occurrence of the interrupt
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: When NMI is activated, the current instruction being executed is completed and then NMI is served. In the case of string instructions, it is served after the complete string is manipulated.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 4. The NMI pin should remain high for atleast
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: The NMI pin should remain high for atleast 2 clock cycles and need not be synchronized with the clock for being sensed.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 5. The INTR signal can be masked by resetting the
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: The INTR signal can be masked by resetting the interrupt flag.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 6. For the INTR signal, to be responded to in the next instruction cycle, it must go ________ in the last clock cycle of the current instruction
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: The INTR signal must go high in the clock cycle of the current instruction in order to respond in the next instruction cycle.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 7. The status of the pending interrupts is checked at
options: a) the end of main program
b) the end of all the interrupts executed
c) the beginning of every interrupt
d) the end of each instruction cycle
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: At the end of each instruction, the status of the pending interrupts is checked.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 8. Once the processor responds to an INTR signal, the IF is automatically
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: The IF is automatically reset when the processor responds to an INTR signal. If the processor wants to respond to any type of INTR signal further then, the IF should again be set.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 9. If the pin LOCK (active low based) is low at the trailing edge of the first ALE pulse, then till the start of the next machine cycle, the pin LOCK (active low) is
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: The pin LOCK (active low) remains low till the start of the next machine cycle.

Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.question: 10. With the trailing edge of the LOCK (active low), the INTA (active low) goes low and remains in it for
Non-Maskable-Interrupt-and-Maskable-Inte.explaination: Explanation: The INTA (active low) goes low and remains low for two clock cycles before returning back to the high state.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 1. The method of defining the interrupt service routine for software is
options: a) same as that of hardware
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: For both software and hardware, the method of defining the interrupt service routine is the same.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 2. While programming for any type of interrupt, the interrupt vector table is set
options: c) either externally or through the program
d) externally and through the program
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: The programmer must, either externally or through the program, set the interrupt vector table for that type preferably with the CS and IP addresses of the interrupt service routine.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 3. To execute a program one should
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: To execute a program, first assemble it, link it and then execute it. After execution, a new file RESULT is created in the directory. Then external pulse is applied to IRQ2 pin, and this will again cause the execution of ISR into the file.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 4. Procedures are also known as
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: Procedures are also known as subroutines.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 5. Procedures, for their execution, require
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: Procedures require input data or constants for their execution. Their data or constants may be passed to the subroutine by the main program.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 6. The technique that is used to pass the data or parameter to procedures in assembly language program is by using
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: The techniques that are used to pass the data or parameter to procedures are by using global declared variable, registers of CPU, memory locations, stack, PUBLIC & EXTRN.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 7. If a procedure is interactive, then
options: a) it accepts inputs directly from input devices
b) it uses global declared variable technique
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: If a procedure is interactive, then it accepts the inputs directly from input devices.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 8. For passing the parameters to procedures using the PUBLIC & EXTRN directives, it must be declared PUBLIC in the
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: For passing the parameters to procedures, it must be declared PUBLIC in the main routine and the same should be declared EXTRN in the procedure.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 9. The technique to estimate the size of an executable program, before it is assembled and linked is
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: There is no technique to estimate the size of an executable program before it is assembled and linked.

Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.question: 10. To estimate the size of an executable program before it is assembled and linked, the programming methodology concerned is by writing
options: a) programs with more than one segment for data and code
b) programs with FAR subroutines each of size up to 64KB
c) programs with more than one segment for stack
Interrupt-Programming,-Passing-Parameter.explaination: Explanation: By writing programs with more than one segment for data, code or stack or by writing programs with FAR subroutines each of size 64KB, the size of an executable program can be estimated.

Macros.question: 1. If a number of instructions are repeating through the main program, then to reduce the length of the program, __________ is used.
Macros.explaination: Explanation: For a certain number of instructions that are repeated in the main program, when macro is defined then the code of a program is reduced by placing the name of the macro at which the set of instructions are needed to be repeated.

Macros.question: 2. The process of assigning a label or macroname to the string is called
Macros.explaination: Explanation: The process of assigning a label to the string is called defining a macro.

Macros.question: 3. A macro within a macro is called
Macros.explaination: Explanation: A macro may be called from inside a macro. This type of macro is called nested macro.

Macros.question: 4. A macro can be defined as
Macros.explaination: Explanation: A macro can be defined anywhere in a program.

Macros.question: 5. A macro can be used as ________
Macros.explaination: Explanation: A macro may be used in data segment and can also be used to represent statements and directives.

Macros.question: 6. The end of a macro can be represented by the directive.
Macros.explaination: Explanation: The ENDM directive marks the end of the instructions or statements sequence assigned with the macro name.

Macros.question: 7. Inserting  the statements and instructions represented by macro, directly at the place of the macroname, in the program, is known as
Macros.explaination: Explanation: Inserting the statements and instructions at the place of macroname, in the program, is known as calling a macro.

Macros.question: 8. The time required for execution of a macro is ________ that of the procedure.
Macros.explaination: Explanation: The time required for execution of a macro is less than that of procedure as it does not contain CALL and RET instructions as the procedures do.

Macros.question: 9. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
options: a) complete code of instruction string is inserted at each place, wherever the macroname appears
b) macro requires less time of execution than that of procedure
d) macroname can be anything except registers and mnemonics
Macros.explaination: Explanation: Macro does not require stack memory and hence has less time for execution.

Macros.question: 10. The beginning of the macro can be represented as
Macros.explaination: Explanation: The beginning of the macro is represented as macroname followed by the directive MACRO.             SYNTAX: macroname MACRO            EXAMPLE: STRINGS MACRO.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 1. If ‘n’ denotes the number of clock cycles and ‘T’ denotes period of the clock at which the microprocessor is running, then the duration of execution of loop once can be denoted by
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: The duration of execution of the loop is the product of number of clock cycles and the period of the clock cycle at which microprocessor is running.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 2. The number of instructions actually executed by the microprocessor depends on the
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: As the microprocessor executes each instruction corresponding loop counter value decreases and the microprocessor executes the instructions till the loop counter becomes zero.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 3. In case of subroutines, the actual number of instructions executed by the processor depends on
options: b) length of interrupt service routine
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: In case of subroutines or interrupt service routines, the number of instructions executed by the processor depends on the length of procedure (or subroutine) or length of interrupt service routine along with the main calling program.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 4. The step included in generating delays is
options: b) selecting instructions for delay loop
c) finding period of clock frequency
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: The delays can be generated step wise.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 5. The Count, N can be defined as
options: c) required delay/number of clock cycles
d) required delay/period of clock frequency
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: The count N can be defined as the required time delay by the duration for execution of the loop once.             Count, N = required delay (Td)/duration for execution of the loop once (n*T).

Timings-and-Delays.question: 6. In the instruction set,
Timings-and-Delays.code:
MOV CX, BA03H
WAIT: DEC CX
      NOP
      JNZ WAIT
      RET
options: if the zeroth condition is satisfied then, for execution, the JNZ instruction takes
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: The JNZ instruction takes only 4 clock cycles if the zeroth condition is satisfied.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 7. In the instruction set,
Timings-and-Delays.code:
MOV CX, BA03H
WAIT: DEC CX
      NOP
      JNZ WAIT
      RET
options: if the zeroth condition is not satisfied, then the JNZ instruction takes
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: The JNZ instruction takes 16 clock cycles if the zeroth condition is not satisfied.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 8. The maximum count value of 16-bit count register puts a limitation on
options: b) storage of address of registers
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: The maximum count value of 16-bit count register is FFFFH. This may put the limitation on the maximum delay that can be generated using the instructions.

Timings-and-Delays.question: 9. When large delays are required, then to serve the purpose
options: a) one or more count registers can be used
b) one or more shift registers can be used
c) one or more pointer registers can be used
d) one or more index registers can be used
Timings-and-Delays.explaination: Explanation: One or more count registers can be used to serve large delays.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 1. The semiconductor memories are organised as __________ dimension(s) of array of memory locations.
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The semiconductor memories are organised as two dimensions of an array which consists of rows and columns.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 2. If a location is selected, then all the bits in it are accessible using a group of conductors called
options: d) either address bus or data bus
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The bits in a selected location are accessible using data bus.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 3. To address a memory location out of N memory locations, the number of address lines required is
options: c) log N (to the base e)
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: For n memory locations, log n(to the base of 2) address lines are required. For addressing 4K bytes of memory, 12 address lines are required since log(4KB) =log(4*1024)=log(212)=12.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 4. If the microprocessor has 10 address lines, then the number of memory locations it is able to address is
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: Since for n address lines, the number of memory locations able to address is 2^n.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 5. In static memory, the upper 8-bit bank of an available 16-bit memory chip is called
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: In static memory, the upper 8-bit bank is called odd address memory bank.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 6. In static memory, the lower 8-bit bank of an available 16-bit memory chip is called
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: In static memory, the lower 8-bit bank is called even address memory bank.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 7. In most of the cases, the method used for decoding that may be used to minimise the required hardware is
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: In general, linear decoding is used to minimise the required hardware.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 8. To obtain 16-bit data bus width, the two 4K*8 chips of RAM and ROM are arranged in
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The two 4K*8 chips of RAM and ROM are arranged in parallel.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 9. If (address line) Ao=0 then, the status of address and memory are
options: a) address is even and memory is in ROM
b) address is odd and memory is in ROM
c) address is even and memory is in RAM
d) address is odd and memory is in RAM
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: If Ao=0 then address is even and is in RAM. If Ao=1 then, address is odd and is in RAM.

Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.question: 10. If at a time Ao and BHE(active low) both are zero then, the chip(s) selected will be
Semiconductor-Memory-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: If at a time Ao and BHE(active low) both are zero, then both RAM and ROM are selected.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 1. The advantage of dynamic RAM is
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The dynamic RAM is advantageous than the static RAM as it has a higher packing density, lower cost and less power consumption.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 2. Whenever a large memory  is required in a microcomputer system, the memory subsystem is generally designed using
options: c) Both static and dynamic RAM
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: Dynamic RAM is preferred for large memory.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 3. If a typical static RAM cell requires 6 transistors then corresponding dynamic RAM requires
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The hardware complexity of dynamic RAM is lesser than that of static RAM.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 4. To store the charge as a representation of data, the basic dynamic RAM cell uses
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The basic dynamic RAM cell uses capacitance to store the charge as a representation of data. This capacitor is manufactured as a diode that is reverse biased so that the storage capacitance is obtained.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 5. The process of refreshing the data in the RAM to reduce the possibility of data loss is known as
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The data storage in RAM which is capacitance (reverse-biased diode) may have a leakage current that tends to discharge the capacitor giving rise to possibility of data loss. To avoid this, the data must be refreshed after a fixed time interval regularly.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 6. The field in which dynamic RAM is more complicated than static RAM is
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The refresh mechanism and the additional hardware required makes the interfacing circuit of dynamic RAM more complicated than that of static RAM.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 7. Memory refresh activity is
options: b) initialised by external bus master
d) initialised either by processor or by external bus
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: The refresh operation is independent regular activity that is initialised and carried out by the refresh mechanism.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 8. The number of memory chips that are enabled at a time for refresh activity is
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: More than one memory chip can be enabled at a time to refresh activity to reduce the number of total memory refresh cycles.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 9. A timer that derives pulse for refreshing action or time for which a dynamic RAM cell can hold data charge level practically constant is
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: Refresh timer derives a pulse for refreshing action after each refresh interval which can be qualitatively defined as the time for which a dynamic RAM cell can hold data charge level practically constant.

Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.question: 10. If ‘n’ denotes the number of rows that are to be refreshed in a single refresh interval, ‘td’ denotes the range of time it may take then, refresh time (tr) can be defined as
Dynamic-RAM-Interfacing.explaination: Explanation: Refresh time is the ratio of time duration taken for refreshing to the number of rows that are refreshed. Refresh frequency is the reciprocal of refresh time.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 1. The device that enables the microprocessor to read data from the external devices is
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: Since joystick is an input device, it reads data from the external devices.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 2. The example of output device is
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: The output device transfers data from the microprocessor to the external devices.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 3. The input and output operations are respectively similar to the operations,
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: The input activity is similar to read operation and the output activity is similar to write operation.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 4. The operation, IOWR (active low) performs
options: a) write operation on input data
b) write operation on output data
c) read operation on input data
d) read operation on output data
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: IOWR (active low) operation means writing data to an output device and not an input device.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 5. The latch or IC 74LS373 acts as
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: If the output port is to source large currents, the port lines must be buffered. So, the latch is used as it acts as a good output port.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 6. While performing read operation, one must take care that much current should not be
options: c) sourced or sinked from data lines
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: More current should not be sourced or sinked from data lines while reading to avoid loading.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 7. To avoid loading during read operation, the device used is
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: A tristate buffer is used as an input device to overcome loading.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 8. The chip 74LS245 is
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: The chip 74LS245 is a bidirectional buffer that contains 8 buffers and may be used as an 8-bit input port. But while using as an input device, only one direction is useful.

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 9. In 74LS245, if DIR is 1, then the direction is from
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: If DIR is 1, then the direction is from A(inputs) to B(outputs).

Interfacing-I/O-Ports.question: 10. In memory-mapped scheme, the devices are viewed as
Interfacing-I/O-Ports.explaination: Explanation: In memory-mapped scheme, the devices are viewed as memory locations and are addressed likewise.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 1. Programmable peripheral input-output port is another name for
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: The parallel input-output port chip 8255 is also known as programmable peripheral input-output port.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 2. Port C of 8255 can function independently as
options: c) either input or output ports
d) both input and output ports
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: Port C can function independently either as input or as output ports.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 3. All the functions of the ports of 8255 are achieved by programming the bits of an internal register called
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: By programming the bits of control word register, the operations of the ports are specified.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 4. The data bus buffer is controlled by
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: The data bus buffer is controlled by read/write control logic.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 5. The input provided by the microprocessor to the read/write control logic is
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: RD(ACTIVE LOW), WR(ACTIVE LOW), A1, A0, RESET are the inputs provided by the microprocessor to the read/write control logic of 8255.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 6. The device that receives or transmits data upon the execution of input or output instructions by the microprocessor is
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: 3-state bidirectional buffer is used to receives or transmits data upon the execution of input or output instructions by the microprocessor.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 7. The port that is used for the generation of handshake lines in mode 1 or mode 2 is
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: Port C upper is used for the generation of handshake lines in mode 1 or mode 2.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 8. If A1=0, A0=1 then the input read cycle is performed from
options: a) port A to data bus
b) port B to data bus
c) port C to data bus
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: If A1=0, A0=1 then the input read cycle is performed from port B to data bus.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 9. The function, ‘data bus tristated’ is performed when
options: c) CS(active low) = 0, RD(active low) = 1, WR(active low) = 1
d) CS(active low) = 1 OR CS(active low) = 0, RD(active low) = 1, WR(active low) = 1
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: The data bus is tristated when chip select pin=1 or chip select pin=0 and read and write signals are high i.e 1.

PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.question: 10. The pin that clears the control word register of 8255 when enabled is
PIO-8255-(Programmable-Input-\u2013-Outp.explaination: Explanation: If reset pin is enabled then the control word register is cleared.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 1. In the I/O mode, the 8255 ports work as
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: In the I/O mode, the 8255 ports work as programmable I/O ports.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 2. In BSR mode, only port C can be used to
options: c) set and reset individual ports
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: In BSR (Bit Set-Reset) Mode, port C can be used to set and reset its individual port bits.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 3. The feature of mode 0 is
options: a) any port can be used as input or output
c) maximum of 4 ports are available
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: In mode 0, any port can be used as input or output and output ports are latched.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 4. The strobed input/output mode is another name of
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: In this mode, the handshaking signals control the input or output action of the specified port.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 5. If the value of the pin STB (Strobe Input) falls to low level, then
options: a) input port is loaded into input latches
b) input port is loaded into output latches
c) output port is loaded into input latches
d) output port is loaded into output latches
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: If the value of the pin STB (Strobe Input) falls to low level, the input port is loaded into input latches.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 6. The signal, SLCT in the direction of signal flow, OUT, indicates the selection of
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: This signal indicates that the printer is selected.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 7. The pulse width of the signal INIT at the receiving terminal must be more than
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: The pulse width of the signal must be more than 50microseconds at the receiving terminal.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 8. The level of the signal ERROR(active low) becomes ‘low’ when the printer is in
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: The level of the signal ERROR(active low) becomes ‘low’ when the printer is in the Paper end state, Offline state and Error state.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 9. The signals that are provided to maintain proper data flow and synchronization between the data transmitter and receiver are
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: Handshaking signals maintain proper data flow and synchronization.

Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.question: 10. The feature of mode 2 of 8255 is
options: b) both inputs and outputs are latched
c) port C is used for generating handshake signals
Modes-of-Operation-of-8255.explaination: Explanation: In mode 2 of 8255, a single 8-bit port is available i.e group A.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 1. The time taken by the ADC from the active edge of SOC(start of conversion) pulse till the active edge of EOC(end of conversion) signal is called
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: Broadly speaking, the time taken by the converter to calculate the equivalent digital data output from the moment of the start of conversion is called conversion delay.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 2. The popular technique that is used in the integration of ADC chips is
options: c) successive approximation and dual slope integration
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: Successive approximation and dual slope integration are the most popular techniques that are used in the integrated ADC chips.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 3. The procedure of algorithm for interfacing ADC contain
options: a) ensuring stability of analog input
b) issuing start of conversion pulse to ADC
c) reading digital data output of ADC as equivalent digital output
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The general algorithm for interfacing ADC contains ensuring the stability of analog input, issuing start of conversion pulse to ADC, reading end of conversion signal to mark the end of a conversion process, reading digital data output of ADC as equivalent digital output.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 4. Which is the ADC among the following?
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: AD 7523 is a DAC(Digital to analog converter), 74373 is a latch, 74245 is transceiver and ICL7109 is an ADC.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 5. The conversion delay in a successive approximation of an ADC 0808/0809 is
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The conversion delay is 100microseconds which is low as compared to other converters.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 6. The number of inputs that can be connected at a time to an ADC that is integrated with successive approximation is
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: As these converters internally have 3:8 analog multiplexer, at a time 8 different analog inputs can be connected to the chip.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 7. ADC 7109 integrated by Dual slope integration technique is used for
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: Compared to other 12-bit ADCs, it is of very low cost and useful for slow practical applications.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 8. Which of the following is not one of the phases of the total conversion cycle?
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: Autozero phase, signal integrate phase and disintegrate phase are the three phases of total conversion cycle.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 9. Which of the following phase contain feedback loop in it?
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: A feedback loop is closed around the system to charge the autozero capacitor to compensate for the offset voltages in the buffer amplifier, integrator and comparator.

Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.question: 10. In the signal integrate phase, the differential input voltage between IN LO(input low) and IN HI(input high) pins is integrated by the internal integrator for a fixed period of
Interfacing-Analog-to-Digital-Data-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The internal integrator needs 2048 clock cycles to integrate voltage difference between input low and input high.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 1. DAC (Digital to Analog Converter) finds application in
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: DAC is used in digitally controlled gains, motor speed controls and programmable gain amplifiers.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 2. To save the DAC from negative transients the device connected between OUT1 and OUT2 of AD 7523 is
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: Zener is connected between OUT1 and OUT2 pins of AD7523 to save from negative transients.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 3. An operational amplifier connected to the output of AD 7523 is used
options: a) to convert current output to output voltage
b) to provide additional driving capability
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: An operational amplifier is used as a current-to-voltage converter to convert the current output to output voltage and also provides additional driving capability to the DAC.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 4. The DAC 0800 has a settling time of
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: DAC 0800 has a settling time of 100 milliseconds.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 5. The device that is used to obtain an accurate position control of rotating shafts in terms of steps is
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: Stepper motor employs rotation of its shaft in terms of steps, rather than continuous rotation as in case of AC or DC motors.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 6. The internal schematic of a typical stepper motor has
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: The internal schematic of a typical stepper motor has 4 windings.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 7. The number of pulses required for one complete rotation of the shaft of the stepper motor is equal to the
options: a) number of internal teeth on a rotor
b) number of internal teeth on a stator
c) number of internal teeth on a rotor and stator
d) number of external teeth on a stator
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: The number of pulses required for one complete rotation of the shaft of the stepper motor is equal to the number of internal teeth on its rotor.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 8. A simple scheme for rotating the shaft of a stepper motor is called
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: In this scheme, the windings are applied with the required voltage pulses, in a cyclic fashion.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 9. The firing angles of thyristors are controlled by
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: In early days, the firing angles were controlled by a pulse generating circuits like relaxation oscillators and now, they are accurately fired using a microprocessor.

Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.question: 10. The Isolation transformers are generally used for
options: c) protecting low power circuit and isolation
Interfacing-Digital-to-Analog-Converters.explaination: Explanation: Any switching component of a high power circuit may be sufficient to damage the microprocessor system. So, to protect the low power circuit isolation transformers are used. They are also used if isolation is necessary.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 1. The number of counters that are present in the programmable timer device 8254 is
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: There are three counters that can be used as either counters or delay generators.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 2. The operation that can be performed on control word register is
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: The control word register can only be written and cannot be read.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 3. The mode that is used to interrupt the processor by setting a suitable terminal count is
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: Mode 0 is also called as an interrupt on the terminal count.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 4. In mode 2, if N is loaded as the count value, then after (N-1) cycles, the output becomes low for
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: After (N-1) cycles, the output becomes low for only 1 clockcycle. If the count N is reloaded and again the output becomes high and remains so for (N-1) clock pulses.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 5. The generation of a square wave is possible in the mode
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: When the count N loaded is even, then for half of the count, the output remains high and for the remaining half it remains low. If the count loaded is odd, the first clock pulse decrements it by 1 resulting in an even count value.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 6. In control word register, if SC1=0 and SC0=1, then the counter selected is
7. In control word format, if RL1=1, RL0=1 then the operation performed is
options: a) read/load least significant byte only
b) read/load most significant byte only
c) read/load LSB first and then MSB
d) read/load MSB first and then LSB
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: To access 16 bit, first LSB is loaded first, and then MSB.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 8. If BCD=0, then the operation is
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: If BCD=0 then hexadecimal count. If BCD=1, then the operation is BCD count.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 9. The counter starts counting only if
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: If the GATE signal is enabled, then the counter starts counting.

Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.question: 10. The control word register contents are used for
Programmable-Interval-Timer-8254.explaination: Explanation: The control word register contents are used fori) initializing the operating modes (mode 0-mode 4)ii) selection of counters (counter0-counter2)iii) choosing binary or BCD countersiv) loading of the counter registers.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 1. The number of hardware interrupts that the processor 8085 consists of is
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: The processor 8085 has five hardware interrupt pins. Out of these five, four pins were alloted fixed vector addresses but the pin INTR was not alloted by vector address, rather an external device was supposed to hand over the type of the interrupt to the microprocessor.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 2. The register that stores all the interrupt requests in it in order to serve them one by one on a priority basis is
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: The interrupts at IRQ input lines are handled by Interrupt Request Register internally.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 3. The register that stores the bits required to mask the interrupt inputs is
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: Also, Interrupt Mask Register operates on IRR(Interrupt Request Register) at the direction of the Priority Resolver.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 4. The interrupt control logic
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: The interrupt control logic performs all the operations that are involved within the interrupts like accepting and managing interrupt acknowledge signals, interrupts.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 5. In a cascaded mode, the number of vectored interrupts provided by 8259A is
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: A single 8259A provides 8 vectored interrupts. In cascade mode, 64 vectored interrupts can be provided.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 6. When the PS(active low)/EN(active low) pin of 8259A used in buffered mode, then it can be used as a
options: a) input to designate chip is master or slave
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: When the pin is used in buffered mode, then it can be used as a buffer enable to control buffer transreceivers. If it is not used in buffered mode, then the pin is used as input to designate whether the chip is used as a master or a slave.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 7. Once the ICW1 is loaded, then the initialization procedure involves
options: a) edge sense circuit is reset
c) slave mode address is set to 7
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: The initialization procedure involvesi) edge sense circuit is reset.ii) IMR is cleared.iii) IR7 input is assigned the lowest priority.iv) slave mode address is set to 7v) special mask mode is cleared and the status read is set to IRR.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 8. When non-specific EOI command is issued to 8259A it will automatically
