Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: When non-specific EOI command is issued to 8259A it will automatically reset the highest ISR.

Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.question: 9. In the application where all the interrupting devices are of equal priority, the mode used is
Programmable-Interrupt-Controller-8259A.explaination: Explanation: The automatic rotation is used in the applications where all the interrupting devices are of equal priority.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 1. The registers that store the keyboard and display modes and operations programmed by CPU are
options: a) I/O control and data buffers
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: The control and timing register to store the keyboard and display modes and other operations programmed by CPU.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 2. The sensor RAM acts as 8-byte first-in-first-out RAM in
options: c) keyboard and strobed input mode
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: In this mode, each key code of the pressed key is entered in the order of the entry, and in the meantime, read by the CPU, till the RAM becomes empty.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 3. The registers that hold the address of the word currently being written by the CPU from the display RAM are
options: b) control and timing register and timing control
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: The display address registers holds the address of the word currently being written or read by the CPU to or from the display RAM.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 4. When a key is pressed, a debounce logic comes into operation in
options: a) scanned keyboard special error mode
b) scanned keyboard with N-key rollover
c) scanned keyboard mode with 2 key lockout
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: In scanned keyboard mode with 2 key lockout mode of operation, when a key is pressed, a debounce logic comes into operation. During the next two scans, other keys are checked for closure and if no other key is pressed then the first pressed key is identified.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 5. The mode that is programmed using “end interrupt/error mode set command” is
options: a) scanned keyboard special error mode
b) scanned keyboard with N-key rollover
c) scanned keyboard mode with 2 key lockout
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: The scanned keyboard special error mode is programmed using end interrupt/error mode set command. This mode is valid only under the N-key rollover mode.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 6. When a key is pressed, the debounce circuit waits for 2 keyboard scans and then checks whether the key is still depressed in
options: a) scanned keyboard special error mode
b) scanned keyboard with N-key rollover
c) scanned keyboard mode with 2 key lockout
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: In this mode, When a key is pressed, the debounce circuit waits for 2 keyboard scans and then checks whether the key is still depressed. If it is still depressed, the code is entered in FIFO RAM.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 7. The data that is entered from the left side of the display unit is of
options: c) left and right entry modes
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: The data that is entered from the left side of the display unit is of left entry mode, as in a type-writer the first character typed appears at the left-most position, while the subsequent characters appear successively to the right of the first one.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 8. The FIFO status word is used to indicate the error in
options: c) keyboard and strobed input mode
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: Overrun error occurs when an already full FIFO has attempted an entry. Underrun error occurs when an empty FIFO read is attempted.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 9. The flag that increments automatically after each read or write operation to the display RAM is
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: AI refers to auto increment flag.

The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.question: 10. If any change in sensor value is detected at the end of a sensor matrix scan, then the IRQ line
The-Keyboard/Display-Controller-8279.explaination: Explanation: In sensor matrix mode, the IRQ line goes high, if any change in sensor value is detected at the end of a sensor matrix scan or the sensor RAM has a previous entry to be read by the CPU.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 1. Which of the following is not a mode of data transmission?
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: Basically, there are three modes of data transmission. simplex, duplex and half duplex.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 2. If the data is transmitted only in one direction over a single communication channel, then it is of
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: In simplex mode, the data transmission is unidirectional. For example, a CPU may transmit data for a CRT display unit in this mode.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 3. If the data transmission takes place in either direction, but at a time data may be transmitted only in one direction then, it is of
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: In half duplex mode, data transmission is bidirectional but not at a time. For example, Walkie-Talkie.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 4. In 8251A, the pin that controls the rate at which the character is to be transmitted is
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: Transmitter Clock Input (TXC(active low)) is a pin that controls the rate at which the character is to be transmitted.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 5. TXD(Transmitted Data Output) pin carries serial stream of the transmitted data bits along with
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: Transmitted Data Output pin carries a serial stream of the transmitted data bits along with other information like start bits, stop bits and parity bits etc.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 6. The signal that may be used either to interrupt the CPU or polled by the CPU is
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: RXRDY(Receiver ready output) may be used either to interrupt the CPU or polled by the CPU.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 7. The disadvantage of RS-232C is
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: RS232C has been used for long and has a few disadvantages like limited speed of communication, high-voltage level signaling and big-size communication adapters.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 8. The USB supports the signaling rate of
options: a) full-speed USB 1.0 at rate of 12 Mbps
b) high-speed USB 2.0 at rate of 480 Mbps
c) super-speed USB 3.0 at rate of 596 Mbps
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: The USB standards support the signaling rates. Also, USB signaling is implemented in a differential in low- and full-speed options.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 9. The bit packet that commands the device either to receive data or transmit data in transmission of USB asynchronous communication is
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: The token packet is the second type of packet which commands the device either to receive data or transmit data.

Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.question: 10. High speed USB devices neglect
Programmable-Communication-Interface-825.explaination: Explanation: PRE packets are only of importance to low-speed USB devices.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 1. In direct memory access mode, the data transfer takes place
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: In direct memory access mode, the data may transfer directly without the interference from the CPU.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 2. In 8257 (DMA), each of the four channels has
options: a) a pair of two 8-bit registers
b) a pair of two 16-bit registers
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: The DMA supports four channels, and each of the channels has a pair of two 16-bit registers, namely DMA address register and a terminal count register.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 3. The common register(s) for all the four channels of 8257 is
options: c) Mode set register and status register
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: The two common registers for all the four channels of DMA are mode set register and status register.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 4. In 8257 register format, the selected channel is disabled after the terminal count condition is reached when
options: c) TC STOP bit is reset
d) TC STOP bit is set
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: If the TC STOP bit is set, the selected channel is disabled after the terminal count condition is reached, and it further prevents any DMA cycle on the channel.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 5. The IOR (active low) input line acts as output in
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: The IOR (active low) is an active low bidirectional tristate input line, that acts as input in the slave mode, and acts as output in the master mode. In master mode, this signal is used to read data from a peripheral during a memory write cycle.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 6. The IOW (active low) in its slave mode loads the contents of a data bus to
options: b) upper/lower byte of 16-bit DMA address register
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: In its slave mode, the IOW (active low) loads the contents of a data bus to 8-bit mode register, upper/lower byte of 16-bit DMA address register or terminal count register.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 7. The pin that disables all the DMA channels by clearing the mode registers is
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: The RESET pin which is asynchronous input disables all the DMA channels by clearing the mode registers, and tristate all the control lines.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 8. The pin that requests the access of the system bus is
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: The hold request output requests the access of the system bus.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 9. The pin that is used to write data to the addressed memory location, during DMA write operation is
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: The MEMW (active low) is used to write data to the addressed memory location, during DMA write operation.

DMA-Controller-8257.question: 10. The pin that strobes the higher byte of the memory address, generated by the DMA controller into the latches is
DMA-Controller-8257.explaination: Explanation: The pin ADSTB strobes the higher byte of the memory address, generated by the DMA controller into the latches.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 1. The 8257 is able to accomplish the operation of
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The 8257 can accomplish three types of operations and they arei) verify DMA operationii) write operationiii) read operation.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 2. The bus is available when the DMA controller receives the signal
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: If the HLDA signal is received by the DMA controller, it indicates that the bus is available.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 3. To indicate the I/O device that its request for the DMA transfer has been honored by the CPU, the DMA controller pulls
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The DACK (active low) line of the used channel is pulled down by the DMA controller to indicate the I/O device that its request for the DMA transfer has been honored by the CPU.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 4. If more than one channel requests service simultaneously, the transfer will occur as
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: If more than one channel requests service simultaneously, then the transfer occurs as a burst or continuous transfer.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 5. The continuous transfer may be interrupted by an external device by pulling down the signal
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The burst or continuous transfer may be interrupted by an external device by pulling down the HLDA line.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 6. The number of clock cycles required for an 8257 to complete a transfer is
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The 8257 uses four clock cycles to complete a transfer.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 7. In 8257, if each device connected to a channel is assigned to a fixed priority then it is said to be in
options: c) rotating priority and fixed priority scheme
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: In this scheme, the DRQ3 has the lowest priority followed by DRQ2 and DRQ1. The DRQ0 has the highest priority.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 8. The priority of the channels varies frequently in
options: c) rotating priority and fixed priority scheme
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: In this scheme, the priorities assigned to the channels are not fixed.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 9. The register of 8257 that can only be written in is
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The selected register may be read or written depending on the instruction executed by the CPU. But only write operation can be performed on the mode set register.

DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.question: 10. The operation that can be performed on the status register is
DMA-Transfers-and-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The status register can only be read.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 1. The block of 8237 that decodes the various commands given to the 8237 by the CPU is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The program control block decodes various commands given to the 8237 by the CPU before servicing a DMA request.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 2. The priority between the DMA channels requesting the services can be resolved by
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The priority encoder block resolves the priority between the DMA channels requesting the services.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 3. The register that holds the current memory address is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The current address register holds the current memory address. The current address register is accessed during the DMA transfer.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 4. The register that holds the data byte transfers to be carried out is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The current word register is a 16-bit register that holds the data transfers. The word count is decremented after each transfer, and the new value is stored again in the register.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 5. When the count becomes zero in the current word register then
options: c) EOP (end of process) is generated
d) Start of process is generated
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: When the count becomes zero, the EOP signal is generated. This can be written in successive bytes by the CPU, in program mode.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 6. The current address register is programmed by the CPU as
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The current address register is byte-wise programmed by the CPU, i.e. lower byte first and the higher byte later.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 7. Which of these register’s contents is used for auto-initialization (internally)?
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The contents of base address register cannot be read by the CPU. These contents are used internally for auto-initialization.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 8. The register that maintains an original copy of the respective initial current address register and current word register is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The base address register maintains an original copy of the current address register and current word register, before incrementing or decrementing.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 9. The register that can be automatically incremented or decremented, after each DMA transfer is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The address is automatically incremented or decremented after each DMA transfer, and the resulting address value is again stored in the current address register.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.question: 10. Which of the following is a type of DMA transfer?
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Memory read, memory write and verify transfer are the three types of DMA transfer.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 1. Each bit in the request register is cleared by
options: c) generation of an external EOP
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: In the request register, each bit is set or reset under program control or is cleared upon generation of a TC or an external EOP.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 2. The register that holds the data during memory to memory data transfer is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The temporary register holds the data during memory to memory data transfers. After the completion of the transfer operation, the last word transferred remains in the temporary register, until it is cleared by a reset operation.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 3. The register that keeps track of all the DMA channel pending requests and status of their terminal counts is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The status register keeps track of all the DMA channel pending requests, and status of their terminal counts. These are cleared upon reset.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 4. The pin that clears the command, request and temporary registers, and internal first/last flipflop when it is set is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: A high on the reset pin clears the command, status, request and temporary registers, and also clears the internal first/last flipflop.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 5. The DMA request input pin that has the highest priority is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: DREQ0 has the highest priority while DREQ3 has the lowest one. The priorities of the DREQ lines is programmable.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 6. When interface 8237 does not have any valid pending DMA request then it is said to be in
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If 8237 is in idle state, then CPU may program it in this state.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 7. To complete a DMA transfer, a memory to memory transfer requires
options: a) a read from memory cycle
b) a write to memory cycle
c) a read-from and write-to memory cycle
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: A memory to memory transfer is a two cycle operation and requires a read from and write-to memory cycle, to complete each DMA transfer.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 8. In demand transfer mode of 8237, the device stops data transfer when
options: a) a TC (terminal count) is reached
b) an external EOP (active low) is detected
c) the DREQ signal goes inactive
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: In demand transfer mode, the device continues transfers till a TC is reached or an external EOP is detected or the DREQ signal goes inactive.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 9. The mode of 8237 in which the device transfers only one byte per request is
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: In single mode, the device transfers only one byte per request. For each transfer, the DREQ must be active until the DACK is activated.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 10. The transfer of a block of data from one set of memory address to another takes place in
options: c) memory to memory transfer mode
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: To perform the transfer of a block of data from one set of a memory address to another one, this transfer mode is used.

Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.question: 11. Which of the following command is used to make all the internal registers of 8237 clear?
Programmable-DMA-Interface-8237-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: Using master clear command, all the internal registers of 8237 are cleared, while all the bits of the mask register are set.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 1. The basic principle of floppy disks involve
options: c) magnetic data recording and reading
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: Whatever their physical sizes and storage formats, all the floppies incorporate the basic principles of magnetic data recording and reading.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 2. In floppy disk, the small hole that enables the drive to identify the beginning of a track and its first sector is
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: The small hole called index hole, enables the drive to identify the beginning of a track and its first sector.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 3. Inside its jacket, the floppy media is rotated at the speed of
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: The floppy media is rotated at the speed of 300 RPM (Revolution Per Minute) inside its jacket.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 4. The Double Density Double Sided disks on each side are organized with
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: The Double Density Double Sided (DDDS) disks are organized with 40 tracks on each side of the disk.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 5. The magnetic recording technique used for storing data onto the disks (floppy disks) is called
options: c) return to zero and Non-return to zero
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: In this technique, the magnetic flux on the disk surface never returns to zero, i.e. no erase operation is carried out.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 6. For reading the disks DVD uses
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: A DVD is an optical disk that uses a red laser for reading the disks.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 7. For reading the disks, the blue ray disk uses
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: The blue ray disk uses a high frequency blue laser with a small wavelength to read the disk.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 8. A blue ray disk can store data upto _________ per layer.
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: A blue ray disk can store data upto 25 GB per layer and is popularly used for storing long duration videos like movies.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 9. DVDRW is for
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: DVDRW is for rewriteable DVD and DVDR is for recordable DVD.

High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.question: 10. The HDD is also called as
High-Storage-Capacity-Memory-Devices.explaination: Explanation: The Hard Disk Drive is also called as a hard disk, hard drive, fixed drive, fixed disk or fixed disk drive.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 1. The 80286 is able to address the physical memory of
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 with its 24-bit address bus is able to address 16 Mbytes of physical memory.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 2. The 80286 is able to operate with the clock frequency of
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: Various versions of 80286 are available that run on 12.5 MHz, 10 MHz and 8 MHz clock frequencies.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 3. The management of the memory system required to ensure the smooth execution of the running process is done by
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The memory management which is an important task of the operating system is now supported by a hardware unit called a memory management unit.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 4. The fetching of the program from secondary memory to place it in physical memory, during the execution of CPU is called
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: Whenever the portion of a program is required for execution by the CPU, it is fetched from the secondary memory and placed in the physical memory. This is called swapping in of the program.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 5. The process of making the physical memory free by storing the portion of program and partial results in the secondary storage called
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: In swapping out, a portion of the program or important partial results required for further execution, may be saved back on secondary storage to make the physical memory free, for further execution of another required portion of the program.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 6. The memory that is considered as a large logical memory space, that is not available physically is
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: To the user, there exists a very large logical memory space, which is actually not available called virtual memory. This does not exist physically in a system. It is however, possible to map a large virtual memory space onto the real physical memory.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 7. Memory management deals with
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The important aspects of memory management are data protection, unauthorized access prevention, and segmented memory.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 8. The memory management and protection mechanisms are disabled when the 80286 is operated in
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: In real address mode of 80286, all the memory management and protection mechanisms are disabled.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 9. The memory management and protection mechanisms are enabled with advanced instruction set when 80286 is operated in
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: In virtual address mode, 80286 works with all of its memory management and protection capabilities, with the advanced instruction set.

Salient-Features-of-80286.question: 10. The 80286 is an upward object code compatible with 8086 or 8088 when operated in
options: d) real and virtual address mode
Salient-Features-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 is operated in two modes, namely real address mode and virtual address mode. In both the modes, the 80286 is compatible with 8086/8088.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 1. The CPU of 80286 contains
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The CPU of 80286 contains the same set of registers as in 8086.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 2. The bits that are modified according to the result of the execution of logical and arithmetic instructions are called
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The flag register bits, D0, D2, D4, D6, D7 and D11 are modified according to the result of the execution of logical and arithmetic instructions. These are called as status flag bits.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 3. The flags that are used for controlling machine operation are called
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The flags such as trap flag (TF) and Interrupt flag (IF) bits are used for controlling the machine operation, and thus they are called control flags.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 4. The additional field that is available in 80286 is
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The additional fields available in 80286 flag register are, I/O Privilege field, nested task flag, protection enable, and monitor processor extension.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 5. Which of the block is not considered as a block of an architecture of 80286?
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The CPU may be viewed to contain four functional parts and they arei) Address Unitii) Bus Unitiii) Instruction Unitiv) Execution Unit.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 6. The unit that is responsible for calculating the address of instructions, and data that the CPU wants to access is
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The address unit is responsible for calculating the address of instructions, and data that the CPU wants to access. Also, the address lines derived by this unit may be used to address different peripherals.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 7. The process of fetching the instructions in advance, and storing in the queue is called
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The instructions are fetched in advance and stored in a queue to enable faster execution of the instructions. This concept is known as instruction pipelining.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 8. The CPU must flush out the prefetched instructions immediately following the branch instruction in
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: In case of unconditional branch, the CPU will have to flush out the prefetched instructions, immediately following the branch instruction.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 9. The device that interfaces and control the internal data bus with the system bus is
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The data transreceivers interface and control the internal data bus with the system bus.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 10. The register bank of Execution Unit of 80286 is used as
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The execution unit contains the register bank, used for storing the data as scratch pad, or used as special purpose registers.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 11. Which of the following is not an interrupt generated by 80286?
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The interrupts generated by 80286 may be divided into 3 categories as external or hardware interrupts, INT instruction or software interrupts and interrupts generated by exceptions.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 12. For which of the following instruction does the return address point to instruction causing an exception?
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: For the instructions, divide error, bound range exceeded and invalid opcode exceptions, the return address points to the instruction causing exception.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 13. The instruction that comes into action, if the trap flag is set is
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: Single step interrupt is an internal interrupt that comes into action if the trap flag (TF) is set.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 14. The interrupt that has the highest priority among the following is
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The instruction exception has the highest priority followed by single step, NMI and INTR instrution.

Internal-Architecture-of-80286.question: 15. The interrupt that has the lowest priority among the following is
Internal-Architecture-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The INT instruction has the lowest priority. The order of priority of interrupts from high to low is1) instruction exception2) single step3) NMI4) processor extension segment overrun5) INTR6) INT instruction.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 1. The 80286 is available in the package as
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 is available in 68-pin PLCC (plastic leaded chip carrier), 68-pin LCC (lead less chip carrier) and 68-pin PGA (pin grid array) packages.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 2. The clock frequency applied at the CLK pin is internally divided by
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The clock frequency is divided by two internally, and is used for deriving fundamental timings for basic operations of the circuit.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 3. The 8 address lines, A23-A16 of 80286 are zero during
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The address lines, A23-A16 are zero during I/O transfers.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 4. The signals S1 (active low), S2 (active low) are
options: b) indicate initiation of bus cycle
c) define type of bus cycle with M/IO (active low)
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The signals S1 (active low), S2 (active low) are active low status output signals, which indicate initiation of a bus cycle, and with M/IO (active low) and COD/INTA (active low), they define the type of the bus cycle.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 5. If M/IO (active low) signal is ‘0’ then it indicates
options: c) I/O cycle or INTA cycle
d) I/O cycle or HALT cycle
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: If M/IO (active low) signal is ‘0’ then it indicates that an I/O cycle or INTA cycle is in the process, and if it is ‘1’, it indicates that a memory or a HALT cycle is in progress.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 6. The LOCK (active low) is activated automatically by hardware using
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The lock pin is used to prevent the other masters from gaining the control of the bus, for the current and the following bus cycles. This pin is activated by a “LOCK” instruction prefix, or automatically by hardware during XCHG, interrupt acknowledge or descriptor table access.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 7. The pin that is used to insert wait states in a bus cycle is
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The active low READY pin is used to insert wait states in a bus cycle, for interfacing low speed peripherals. This signal is neglected during HLDA cycle.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 8. The minimum number of clock cycles required in an input pulse width of the RESET pin is
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: The active high RESET input clears the internal logic of 80286, and re-initializes it. The reset input pulse width should be at least 16 clock cycles.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 9. To filter the output, a 0.047microfarads, 12V capacitor is connected between the pins
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: A 0.047microfarads, 12V capacitor is connected between the CAP pin and ground, to filter the output of the internal substrate bias generator.

Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.question: 10. The signal that causes the 80286 to perform the processor extension interrupt while executing the WAIT and ESC instructions are
Signal-Descriptions-of-80286.explaination: Explanation: An active ERROR (active low) signal causes the 80286 to perform the processor extension interrupt while executing the WAIT and ESC instructions.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 1. The 80286 CPU acts just like that of 8086 when operated in
options: c) real and protected virtual address modes
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: In the real addressing mode of operation of 80286, it just acts as a fast 8086.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 2. In real addressing mode, the 80286 addresses a physical memory of
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: In real addressing mode, the 80286 addresses a physical memory of 1 Mbytes using A0-A19. The lines A20-A23 are not used by the internal circuit of 80286 in this mode.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 3. In real addressing mode, the 80286 operates at a speed
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: Because of extra pipelining and other circuit level improvements, in real address mode also, the 80286 operates at a much faster rate than 8086.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 4. In physical memory, if the segment size limit is exceeded by the instruction or data then
options: c) saves to next segment automatically
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: An exception is generated if the segment size limit is exceeded by the instruction or the data.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 5. The 80286 reserves fixed area of physical memory for
options: c) system initialization and interrupt vector table
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 reserves two fixed areas of physical memory for system initialization and interrupt vector table.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 6. In the real mode, the memory that is reserved for interrupt vector table is
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: In the real mode, the first 1 Kbyte of memory starting from the address 00000H to 003FFH, is reserved for interrupt vector table.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 7. In the real mode, the memory that is reserved for system initialization is
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: The addresses from FFFF0H to FFFFFH are reserved for system initialization, in real addressing mode.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 8. When 80286 is reset, it always starts its execution in
options: c) either real or protected virtual address modes
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation:  When 80286 is reset, it always starts its execution in real addressing mode.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 9. The 80286 in real addressing mode performs
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 in real addressing mode performs the following functions: it initializes IP and other registers of 80286, initializes the peripheral, enables interrupts, sets up descriptor tables, and then prepares it for entering the protected virtual address mode.

Real-Addressing-Mode.question: 10. In real address mode, while addressing the physical memory, the 80286 uses the signal
Real-Addressing-Mode.explaination: Explanation: In real address mode, while addressing the physical memory, the 80286 uses BHE (active low) along with A0-A19.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 1. The procedure of fetching the chosen program segments or data from the secondary storage into the physical memory is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: Swapping is the procedure of fetching the chosen program segments or data from the secondary storage into the physical memory.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 2. The procedure of storing back the partial results on to the secondary storage is called
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The procedure of storing back the partial results or data back on to the secondary storage is called unswapping.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 3. The ability of 80286 to address the virtual memory per task is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 is able to address 1Gbyte of virtual memory per task.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 4. The branch instructions are handled by
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The handling of branch instructions like JUMP and CALL is taken care of, by the swapping and unswapping mechanism, and operating system.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 5. A descriptor contains information of
options: c) regarding segment and its access rights
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The segments or pages have been associated with a data structure known as a descriptor. The descriptor contains information on the page, and also carry relevant information regarding a segment, and its access rights.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 6. The descriptors that are used for subroutines and interrupt service routines are
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: For data segment, the corresponding descriptor may be data segment descriptor and for code segment, there may be code segment descriptor. For subroutines and interrupt service routines there are gate descriptors.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 7. A segment with low privilege level is not allowed to access another segment of
options: c) low and high privilege level
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: A segment with low privilege level is not allowed to access another segment with high privilege level.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 8. A descriptor is used to carry out
options: c) to store privilege level and segment limit
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: A descriptor is used to carry out additional functions like transfer of control and task switching.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 9. The descriptor that is used for special system data segments and control transfer operations is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 has system segment descriptor, that is used for special system data segments, and control transfer operations.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 10. A code segment descriptor contains
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: A code or data segment descriptor contains 16-bit segment limit, 24-bit segment base address, 8-bit access rights byte and the remaining 16-bits are reserved by Intel for upward compatibility.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 11. In access rights byte, if P (Present)=1, then the segment is mapped into
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: If P=1, then the segment is mapped into physical memory.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 12. In access rights byte, to select system segment descriptor, the condition is
options: c) S not equal to zero
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: If S (segment descriptor)=0, then system segment descriptor or gate descriptor is selected.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 13. If S (segment descriptor)=1, then the descriptor selected is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: If S=1, then code or data (including stack) segment descriptors are selected.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 14. The memory of limit field is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The limit field, which is the maximum allowed offset address, is of 16 bits.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 1. Which of the following is a type of system segment descriptor?
options: c) system descriptor and gate descriptor
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The system segment descriptors are of seven types. The types 1 to 3 are called system descriptors and the types 4 to 7 are called gate descriptors.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 2. Which of the following is a type of gate descriptor?
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The gate descriptors are of four types namely, call gate, task gate, interrupt gate and trap gate.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 3. The gate descriptor contains the information of
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The gate descriptor contains the information regarding the destination of control transfer, required stack manipulations, privilege level and its type.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 4. The gate that is used to alter the privilege levels is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: Call gates are used to alter the privilege levels.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 5. The gate that is used to specify a corresponding service routine is
options: a) call gate and trap gate
b) task gate and interrupt gate
c) interrupt gate and trap gate
d) task gate and trap gate
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: Interrupt gates and trap gates are used to specify corresponding service routines.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 6. The gate that is used to switch from one task to another is
options: c) task gate and trap gate
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: Task gate is used to switch from one task to another.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 7. The gate that uses word count field is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The word count field is only used by a call gate descriptor, to indicate the number of bytes to be transferred from the stack of the calling routine to the stack of the called routine.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 8. The memory that maintains the most frequently required data for execution, in a high speed memory is called
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: To minimize the time required for fetching the frequently required descriptor information, from the main memory, cache memory is used in which the most frequently required data for execution is stored.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 9. The selector field consists of
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: In the protected mode, the contents of the segment registers are known as selectors. The selector field consists of three fields namely, RPL, table indicator (TI) and index.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 10. If table indicator, TI=0, then the descriptor table selected is
options: c) local and global descriptor table
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The type of descriptor table is global if TI=0 and local if TI=1.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 11. The instruction that is executed at privilege level zero (0) is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The LGDT and LLDT instructions are privileged, and may be executed only at privilege level 0.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 12. The instruction that loads a selector which refers to a local descriptor table, containing the base address and limit for LDT is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The LLDT instruction loads a selector, which refers to a local descriptor table, containing the base address, and limit for LDT.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 13. The descriptor that is used to store task gates, interrupt gates and trap gates is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 has a third type of descriptor table known as interrupt descriptor table, which is used to store task gates, interrupt gates and trap gates.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 14. The number of interrupt descriptors that the interrupt descriptor table (IDT) handles is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: The IDT is able to handle upto 256 interrupt descriptors.

Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.question: 15. The number of bytes required for an interrupt in an IDT is
Protected-Virtual-Address-Mode-(PVAM)-\u.explaination: Explanation: Six bytes are required for each interrupt in an interrupt descriptor table.

Privilege.question: 1. By using privilege mechanism the protection from unauthorized accesses is done to
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: The operating system, interrupt handlers and other system softwares can be protected from unauthorized accesses in virtual address space of each task using the privilege mechanism.

Privilege.question: 2. The task privilege level at the instant of execution is called
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: Any one of the four privilege levels may be used to execute a task. The task privilege level at that instant is called the Current Privilege Level (CPL).

Privilege.question: 3. Once the CPL is selected, it can be changed by
options: b) transferring control using system descriptors
c) transferring control using gate descriptors
d) transferring control using interrupt descriptors
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: Once the CPL is selected, it cannot be changed during the execution normally in a single code segment. It can only be changed by transferring the control, using gate descriptors, to a new segment.

Privilege.question: 4. The data segments defined in GDT (global descriptor table) and the LDT (local descriptor table) can be accessed by a task with
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: A task executing at level 0, the most privileged level, can access all the data segments defined in GDT and the LDT of the task.

Privilege.question: 5. A task with privilege level 0, doesn’t refer to all the lower level privilege descriptors in
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: The task with privilege level 0, refers to all the lower level privilege descriptors which apply to all the descriptors except the LDT descriptors.

Privilege.question: 6. The selector RPL that uses a less trusted privilege than the current privilege level for further use is known as
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: A selector RPL uses a less trusted privilege than the current privilege level for further use. This is known as the Effective Privilege Level of the task.

Privilege.question: 7. The effective privilege level is
options: a) maximum numeric of RPL and CPL
b) minimum privilege of RPL and CPL
c) numeric minimum and privilege maximum of RPL and CPL
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: The effective privilege level is minimum in numeric and maximum in the privilege of RPL and CPL.

Privilege.question: 8. The task requesting an access to a descriptor is allowed to access after checking the
options: c) type of descriptor and privilege level
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: The task requesting an access to a descriptor is allowed to access to it and to the corresponding segment, only after checking the type of the descriptor and privilege level(CPL, RPL, DPL).

Privilege.question: 9. A CALL instruction can reference only a code segment descriptor with
options: a) DPL less privilege than CPL
b) DPL equal privilege to CPL
c) DPL greater privilege than CPL
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: A CALL or JUMP instruction can reference only a code segment descriptor with DPL equal to CPL of the task or a segment with a DPL of equal or greater privilege than CPL.

Privilege.question: 10. The RPL of a selector that referred to the code descriptor must have
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: The RPL of a selector that referred to the code descriptor must have the same privilege as CPL.

Privilege.question: 11. The instruction that refers to only code segment descriptors with DPL equal to or less than the task CPL is
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: The RET and IRET instructions are to refer to only code segment descriptors with DPL equal to or less than the task CPL.

Privilege.question: 12. When a JUMP instruction references a Task State Segment(TSS) descriptor, then DPL must be
options: b) greater or equally privileged than CPL
c) less or equally privileged than CPL
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: When a CALL or JUMP instruction references a Task State Segment(TSS) descriptor, then DPL must be less or equally privileged than CPL.

Privilege.question: 13. The data segment access refers to
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: Loading DS, ES or SS for referring to a new descriptor comes under the data segment access.

Privilege.question: 14. An exception is generated when
options: b) an improper segment is referenced
c) referenced segment is not present in physical memory
Privilege.explaination: Explanation: If the privilege test is negative or an improper segment is referenced then an exception 13 is generated. If the referenced segment is not present in physical memory, an exception 11 is generated.

Protection.question: 1. The mechanism to provide protection, that is accomplished with the help of read/write privileges is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: The restricted use of segments is accomplished with the help of read/write privileges.

Protection.question: 2. The Local descriptor table (LDT) and Global descriptor table (GDT) are present in
Protection.explaination: Explanation: In restricted use of segments i.e. segment load check, the segment usages are restricted by classifying the corresponding descriptors, under LDT and GDT.

Protection.question: 3. The mechanism that is accomplished using descriptor usages limitations and rules of privilege check is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: Restricted accesses to segment, also called, operation reference check, is accomplished using descriptor usages limitations, and rules of privilege check.

Protection.question: 4. The mechanism that is executed at certain privilege levels, determined by CPL (Current Privilege Level) and I/O privilege level (IOPL) is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: The privileged instructions or operations, also called, privileged instruction check, is executed at certain privilege levels, determined by CPL and I/O privilege level(IOPL), as defined by the flag register.

Protection.question: 5. If CPL is not of the required privilege level, then the instructions that get affected is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: The IRET and POPF instructions do not perform any of their functions, if CPL is not of the required privilege level.

Protection.question: 6. If CPL is greater than zero, then the instruction that remains unaffected is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: IF remains unaffected if CPL is greater than zero. No exception is generated for this condition.

Protection.question: 7. The condition, “CPL not equals to zero” satisfies when executing the instruction
Protection.explaination: Explanation: The condition, “CPL not equals to zero” satisfies, when executing the instructions, LIDT, LGDT, LTR, LMSW, CTS and HLT.

Protection.question: 8. While executing the instruction IN/OUT, the condition of CPL is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: The condition CPL>IOPL exists, when executing the instructions, INs, IN, OUTS, OUT, STI, CLI and LOCK.

Protection.question: 9. The instruction at which the exception is generated, but the processor extension registers contain the address of failing instruction is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: At the ESC instruction, the exception is generated, but the processor extension registers contain the address of failing instruction.

Protection.question: 10. The exception that has no error code on a stack is
Protection.explaination: Explanation: The processor extension segment overrun has no error code on the stack.

Protection.question: 11. Which of the following is protected mode exception?
Protection.explaination: Explanation: Double exception detected, invalid task state segment, stack segment overrun, processor extension segment overrun, are the protected mode exceptions.

Special-Operations.question: 1. Which of the following operation is not carried out by 80286?
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 carries out six operations. They are:1. processor reset and initialization2. task switch operation3. pointer testing instructions4. protected mode initialization5. how to enter protected mode?6. halt.

Special-Operations.question: 2. After completion of the first cycle, the first task is again scheduled for the next cycle. This process is known as
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: After completion of the first cycle, the first task is again scheduled for the next cycle, and the process continues. The previous task that was incomplete, may be completed during its coming turns of the allotted CPU time slice. This switch-over operation from one task to another is called task switch operation.

Special-Operations.question: 3. The operation that is provided by the internal architecture, to save the execution state of a task is
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 internal architecture provides a task switch operation, to save the execution state of a task, and to load a new task to be executed.

Special-Operations.question: 4. The instruction that can be used to carry out task switch operation is
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: A software interrupt instruction, exception or external interrupt, can also be used to carry out task switch operation.

Special-Operations.question: 5. The IRET instruction gets back the execution state of the previous task, if
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: If NT = 1, the IRET instruction gets back the execution state of the previous task. Otherwise, the IRET instruction lets the current task continue, after popping the required values from the stack.

Special-Operations.question: 6. The NT flag is set by the task switch operation, that is initiated by
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The NT flag is set by CALL or INT initiated task switch operations.

Special-Operations.question: 7. The 80286 executes LMSW instruction to enter into
options: c) real addressing and protected modes
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: To enter into protected mode, 80286 executes LMSW instruction, that sets PE flag.

Special-Operations.question: 8. The instruction that sets the zero flag, if the segment referred to, by the selector can be read is
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The VERR (VERify to Read) instruction sets the zero flag, if the segment referred to, by the selector, can be read.

Special-Operations.question: 9. The instruction that sets the zero flag, if the segment referred to by the selector, can be written as
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The VERW (VERify to Write) instruction sets the zero flag, if the segment referred to, by the selector can be written.

Special-Operations.question: 10. The instruction that reads the descriptor access rights byte into the register is
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The LAR (Load Access Rights) instruction reads the descriptor access rights byte into the register, if privilege rules allow.

Special-Operations.question: 11. The instruction that reads the segment limit into the register, if privilege rules and descriptor type allow is
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The LSL (Load Segment Limit) instruction reads the segment limit into the register, if privilege rules, and descriptor type allow.

Special-Operations.question: 12. The instruction that adjusts the RPL (Requested Privilege Level) of the selector, to the numeric maximum of current selector RPL value is
Special-Operations.explaination: Explanation: The APRL (Adjust Requested Privilege Level) adjusts the RPL (Requested Privilege Level) of the selector to the numeric maximum of current selector RPL value, and the RPL value in the register.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 1. Which of the following is a supporting chip of 80286?
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The interrupt controller 8259A, clock generator 82C284, and bus controller 82C288 are the unavoidable members of the family, of supporting chips of 80286.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 2. In minimum mode, the function of 80286 is
options: a) data transfers to/from memory or I/O
b) controls the data transfer of 80287
c) controls the instruction execution of 80287
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: In a minimum mode, the 80286 carries out all the data transfers to/from memory or I/O, controls the data transfer, and instruction execution of 80287.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 3. The signal that is applied to the decoding logic, to differentiate between interrupt, code fetch and data bus cycles is
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The COD, INTA (active low), M/IO (active low) signals are applied to the decoding logic, to differentiate between interrupt, I/O, code fetch, and data bus cycles.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 4. By adding which of the following, the minimum mode of 80286 gives the multibus interface of 80286?
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The addition of single chip 82C289 known as bus arbiter, to the configuration of 80286 minimum mode, gives the multibus structure of 80286.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 5. The number of bus controllers that are used for interfacing of memory and I/O devices is
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The interfacing of memory and I/O devices, uses two 82288 bus controllers, one each for local, and system bus.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 6. If the 80286 need to use system bus, then the signal that is to be active is
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The ARDYEN pin is to be activated if the 80286 is to use the system bus. The SRDYEN pin is to be grounded.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 7. If MBYTES input is high, then the pin serves as
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The MBYTES input selects the function of AEN/CEN pin. If MBYTES is high, the pin serves as AEN, else it serves as CEN. The CEN pin is used for selecting one of the available 82288s.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 8. Latches are used in 80286 to
options: a) demultiplex the address and data lines
d) latch the address and decode the select signals
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The address and data lines are not multiplexed, hence no latches are required in 80286 system. Rather the addresses of the next bus cycle are displayed in advance, hence the latches are required for latching the address, and decode the signals.

80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.question: 9. The I/O port addresses, that are not used, while designing practical systems around 80286 are
80286-Minimum-System-Configuration,--Int.explaination: Explanation: The I/O port addresses 00F8H to 00FFH are reserved by Intel, hence these should not be used while designing practical systems around 80286.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 1. Which of the following is the highest priority usage among them?
options: a) second transfer cycle of a processor extension data transfer
b) third transfer cycle of a processor extension data transfer
d) second byte transfer of 2-byte transfer at an odd address
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The second byte transfer of 2-byte transfer at an odd address, is the highest priority usage among the given usages.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 2. The highest priority usage than any other usage is
options: a) transfer with LOCK (active low) signal
d) data transfer performed by EU (execution unit)
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The transfer with LOCK (active low) signal is the highest priority usage than any other usage.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 3. The lowest priority usage among the following is
options: c) prefetch operation to fetch and arrange next instruction bytes in queue
d) data transfer performed by EU for instruction execution
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The order of priority usages, starting from the highest one to the lowest one, is given as1. transfer with LOCK (active low) signal2. second byte transfer of 2-byte transfer at an odd address3. second or third transfer cycle of a processor extension data transfer4. HOLD request5. processor extension data transfer6. data transfer performed by EU (execution unit)7. prefetch operation to fetch and arrange next instruction bytes in queue.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 4. As a response to the valid bus hold request, the bus is pushed into
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: 80286 local bus is relinquished for another bus master if a valid bus hold request is received at the HOLD input pin. As a response to a valid bus hold request, the bus is pushed into TH state.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 5. The bus arbiter relinquishes
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The address, M/IO (active low) and COD/INTA (active low) are relinquished by bus arbiter.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 6. A valid HOLD request is ascertained only after the completion of
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: Only after 34 clockcycles, after the 80286 is reset, a valid HOLD request should be ascertained.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 7. The master PIC 8259A decides which of its slave interrupt controllers is to return the vector address, as a response of
options: a) first INTA (active low) pulse from 80286
b) second INTA (active low) pulse from 80286
c) third INTA (active low) pulse from 80286
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: In response to the first INTA (active low) pulse from 80286, the master PIC 8259A decides, which of its slave interrupt controllers is to return the vector address.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 8. The slave (which is selected) sends the vector on data bus after the
options: a) first INTA (active low) pulse from 80286
b) second INTA (active low) pulse from 80286
c) third INTA (active low) pulse from 80286
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The interrupt acknowledge sequence consists of two INTA (active low) pulses. After the second pulse, the selected slave sends the vector on D0-D7 data lines, and 80286 reads it.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 9. The signal of 82C288, that enables the cascade address drivers, during INTA cycles is
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The MCE (Master Cascade Enable) signal of 82C288 enables the cascade address drivers during INTA cycles, to select the slave using the local address bus.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 10. The LOCK (active low) signal is activated during
options: a) Ti of first INTA cycle
b) Ts of first INTA cycle
c) Th of second INTA cycle
d) Ts of second INTA cycle
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The LOCK (active low) signal is activated during Ts of first INTA cycle.

Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.question: 11. The number of idle states (Ti), that is allowed between two INTA cycles, to meet the 8259A speed and cascade address output delay is
Priority-of-Bus-Use-By-80286,-Bus-Hold-a.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 allows three idle states (Ti) between the two INTA cycles, to meet the 8259A speed and cascade address output delay.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 1. In which of these modes, the immediate operand is included in the instruction itself?
options: c) register and immediate operand mode
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In immediate operand mode, the immediate operand is included in the instruction itself.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 2. In register address mode, the operand is stored in
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In register address mode, the operand is stored either in one of the 8-bit or 16-bit general purpose registers or in SI, DI, BX or BP.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 3. In which of the following addressing mode, the offset is obtained by adding displacement and contents of one of the base registers?
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In a based mode, the offset is obtained by adding displacement and contents of one of the base registers, either BX or BP.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 4. In which of the following addressing mode, the offset is obtained by adding displacement, with the contents of SI?
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In an indexed mode, the offset is obtained by adding displacement, with contents of an index register, either SI or DI.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 5. The address of a location of the operand is calculated by adding the contents of any of the base registers, with the contents of any of index registers in
options: a) based indexed mode with displacement
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In a based indexed mode, the operand is stored at a location, whose address is calculated by adding the contents of any of the base registers, with the contents of any of the index registers.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 6. Which of the following is not a data type of 80286?
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The 80286 supports seven data types. They are1. integer2. Ordinal (unsigned)3. pointer4. string5. ASCII6. BCD7. Packed BCD.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 7. The representation of 8-bit or 16-bit signed binary operands using 2’s complement is a data type of
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In integer data type, 8-bit or 16-bit signed binary operands are represented using 2’s complement.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 8. The instruction that pushes the general purpose registers, pointer and index registers on to the stack is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The PUSH*A instruction, pushes the general purpose registers, AX, CX, DX and BX, pointer and index registers, SP, BP, SI, DI, on to the stack.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 9. While executing the PUSH*A instruction, the stack pointer is decremented by
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The stack pointer is decremented by 16 (eight 2-byte registers).

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 10. The statement that is true for the instruction POP*A is
options: c) exceptions generated are same as that of PUSH*A
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The POP*A instruction, pops all the contents of the registers DI, SI, BP, SP, BX, DX, CX and AX from the stack in this sequence, that is exactly opposite to that of pushing.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 11. The instruction that multiplies the content of AL with a signed immediate operand is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The IMUL instruction multiplies the content of AL with a signed immediate operand, and the signed 16-bit result is stored in AX.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.question: 12. The instruction that represents the ‘rotate source, count’ is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The rotate source, count is a group of four instructions containing RCL, RCR, ROL, ROR.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 1. In ‘Rotate source, count’ instructions, if the CF is equal to MSB of operand (source) then
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If CF is equal to MSB of operand (source), the overflow flag is cleared, otherwise, it is set to 1.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 2. The instruction that affects the flags is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: No flags are affected by the instructions, INSW, INSB and POP*A.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 3. A general protection exception is generated, if the value of
options: a) CPL is equal to that of IOPL
b) CPL is less than that of IOPL
c) CPL is greater than that of IOPL
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: When the value of CPL is greater than that of IOPL, a general protection exception is generated.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 4. While executing the instruction, OUTSW, the SI is incremented by
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The SI is automatically incremented by 1 for byte (OUTSB) and 2 for word (OUTSW) operations.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 5. The instruction that is used to exit the procedure is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The instruction, LEAVE, is generally used with high level languages, to exit a procedure.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 6. The instruction that determines the number of bytes, to be copied into the new stack frame, from the previous stack is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The ENTER instruction prepares a stack structure for parameters of a procedure to be executed further. This instruction determines the number of bytes to be copied, into the new stack frame, from the previous stack.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 7. The instruction that is used to check whether a signed array offset is within the limit, defined for it by the starting and ending index is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The BOUND instruction is used to check whether a signed array offset is within the limit defined for it, by the starting and ending index.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 8. The CLTS (Clear Task Switch Flag) instruction records every execution of WAIT and ESC and is trapped if the flag(s)
options: a) PE (Protection Enable) and TS (task switch) flags are set
b) Emulate Processor extension flag is set
c) MP flag and task switched flag is set
d) PE and MP flag is set
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The CLTS (Clear Task Switch Flag) instruction records every execution of WAIT and ESC, and is trapped, if the MP flag and task switched flag is set.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 9. The instruction that determines whether the segment pointed to, by a 16-bit register, can be accessed from the current privilege level is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The VERR/VERW instructions determine whether the segment pointed to, by a 16-bit register, can be accessed from the current privilege level.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 10. The instruction that loads 6 bytes from a memory block, pointed to by the effective address of the operand, into global descriptor table register is
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The LGDT (load global descriptor table register) loads 6 bytes from a memory block, pointed to by the effective address of the operand, into global descriptor table register.

Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.question: 11. In LGDT instruction, while loading 6 bytes, the first word is loaded into the field of
options: c) Either LIMIT or BASE field
Instruction-Set-Features-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: While loading the 6 bytes, the first word is loaded into the LIMIT field of the descriptor table register. The next three bytes are loaded into the BASE field of the register, and the remaining byte is ignored.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 1. Which of the following is not a block of an architecture of 80287?
options: b) data interface and control unit
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The three blocks of an internal architecture of 80287 are:1. bus control logic2. data interface and control unit3. floating point unit.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 2. The unit that provides and controls the interface, between the internal 80287 bus and 80286 bus via data buffer is
options: b) data interface and control unit
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The bus control logic provides and controls the interface, between the internal 80287 bus and 80286 bus via data buffer.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 3. The data interface and control unit consists of
options: b) tag words and error pointers
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The data interface and control unit contains status and controls words, TAG words and error pointers.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 4. The word that optimizes the NDP performance, by maintaining a record of empty and non-empty register locations is
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The TAG word optimizes the NDP performance by maintaining a record of empty and non-empty register locations. It helps the exception handler to identify special values in the contents of the stack locations.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 5. The part of the data interface and control unit, that points to the source of exception generated is
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The error pointers point to the source of exception (address of the instruction that generated the exception) generated.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 6. The data bus in a floating point unit is of
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The data bus in a floating point unit is of 84-bits. Out of this 84-bits, the lower 68 bits are significant (mantissa) data bit, the next 16 bits are used for the exponent.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 7. The arrangement of data that is to be shifted successively, whenever required for the execution, is done by
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The barrel shifter arranges and presents the data to be shifted successively, whenever required for the execution.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 8. The word that is used to select one of the processing options, among the provided ones is
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The control word is used to select one of the processing options, among the ones provided by 80287.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 9. After reset of 80287, the control bit that is initialized to zero is
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The infinity control bit is initialized to zero after reset.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.question: 10. The bits that are modified depending upon the result of the execution of arithmetic instructions are
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The condition code bits are similar to the flags of a CPU. These are modified depending upon the result of the execution of arithmetic instructions.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-2.question: 1. If the stack flag is set, and condition code bit C1=1, then the stack is
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If the stack flag is set, and condition code bit C1=1, then the stack has overflown.

80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-2.question: 2. If the stack flag is set, and condition code bit C1=0, then the stack is
80287-Math-Coprocessor-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If the stack flag is set, and condition code bit C1=0, then the stack has underflown.
