Rapid-Execution-Module,-Memory-Subsystem.explaination: Explanation: Threads may be bunched together in a process. Threads are independent, simple in structure and are lightweight in the sense that they may enhance the speed of operation of an overall process.

Rapid-Execution-Module,-Memory-Subsystem.question: 8. The process in which multiple threads correspond to the tracking of each individual object is known as
Rapid-Execution-Module,-Memory-Subsystem.explaination: Explanation: The mutiple threads correspond to the tracking of each individual object. This kind of parallelism is known as thread level parallelism(TLP).

Rapid-Execution-Module,-Memory-Subsystem.question: 9. Which of the following is not a type of context switching?
Rapid-Execution-Module,-Memory-Subsystem.explaination: Explanation: A single processor can execute multiple threads by switching between them. The scheme of context switching may be several types. They are1. Time-slice multithreading2. On chip multiprocessing3. Hyperthreading.

Rapid-Execution-Module,-Memory-Subsystem.question: 10. The thread level parallelism is a process of
options: a) saving the context of currently executing process
b) flushing the CPU of the same process
c) loading the context of new next process
Rapid-Execution-Module,-Memory-Subsystem.explaination: Explanation: The thread level parallelism is a process of1. Saving the context of currently executing process.2. Flushing the CPU of the same process.3. Loading the context of new next process is called a context switch.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 1. Which of the following is a resource sharing strategy that had been investigated by the developers?
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: Several resource sharing strategies have been investigated by the developers. Some of these are1. Partitioned resources2. Threshold sharing3. Full sharing.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 2. The feature of hyperthreading is
options: c) effective use of processor resources
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: Hyperthreading used the concept of simultaneous multithreading, where multiple threads can be executed on a single processor without switching.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 3. Each logical processor maintains a set of architecture state which consists of
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: Each logical processor maintains a set of architecture state which consists of1. Registers including the general purpose registers2. The control register3. Advanced programmed interrupt controller4. Machine state register.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 4. A logical processor may be temporarily stalled for
options: c) waiting for results of previous instructions
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: A logical processor may be temporarily stalled for a variety of reasons like including servicing cache misses, handling branch mispredictions and waiting for results of previous instructions.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 5. The hyperthreading technology automatically involves the
options: c) decrease of die area to half
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: The hyperthreading technology automatically involves the increase of die area.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 6. The instruction that is used when either of the logical processors is idle is
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: An optimization may require the use of HALT instruction, when either of the two logical processors is idle.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 7. The mode that is available when there is only one software thread to execute is
options: c) single task and multi task mode
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: When there is only one software thread to execute, there are two modes namely single task mode and multi task mode.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 8. The HALT instruction is a privileged instruction that can be only used by
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: The HALT instruction is a privileged instruction that can be only used by operating system.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 9. When the operating system uses HALT instruction on a processor which supports multithreading, the operation moves from
options: a) Single task to multi task mode
c) Multi task to single task mode
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: When the operating system uses HALT instruction on a processor which supports multithreading, the operation moves from multi tasking mode to single tasking mode.

Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.question: 10. The Xeon TM processor on which hyperthreading technology was first implemented consists of
options: a) one logical processor per physical processor
b) two logical processor per physical processor
c) three logical processor per physical processor
d) zero logical processor per physical processor
Hyperthreading-In-Pentium.explaination: Explanation: The Xeon TM processor on which hyperthreading technology was first implemented consists of two logical processor per physical processor.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 1. The MMX instructions support only
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The MMX instructions support only integer data type.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 2. For single precision floating point numbers, the SSE instructions are
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The SSE instructions are SIMD(Single Instruction Multiple Data Stream) instructions for single precision floating point numbers.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 3. The feature of SSE among the following is
options: a) operate on four 32-bit floating points
b) register size is of 128 bits
c) no switching from one mode to other
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The features of SSE(Streaming SIMD extensions) are1. SSE instructions are SIMD instructions for single precision floating point numbers.2. They operate on four 32-bit floating points.3. The register size is of 128 bits4. No necessity to switch from one mode to other.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 4. The new instructions that are added in SSE for floating point operations are of
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The new instructions that are added in SSE for floating point operations are 50.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 5. The SSE instructions can operate on
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The SSE instructions can operate on packed data or scalar data.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 6. Which of the following group is not of SSE instructions?
options: a) jump or branch group of instruction
b) logic and comparison group of instruction
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The SSE instructions can be grouped to many types. Some of them are1. Data transfer instructions2. Arithmetic, logic and comparison group of instruction3. shuffle instructions4. Cacheability instructions.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 7. Which of the following is true about SSE2 instructions in Pentium III and Pentium 4?
options: a) SSE increases the accuracy of double precision floating point operations
b) SSE supports new formats of packed data
c) SSE increases the speed of manipulation of SIMD integer operations
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The SSE new instruction set increases the accuracy of double precision floating point operations, supports new formats of packed data.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 8. The data type that the SSE2 instructions doesn’t support is
options: c) single and double precision floating points
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The SSE2 instructions support new data types such as double precision floating points along with single precision floating points.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 9. The additional instructions of SSE3 over SSE2 contains
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The SSE3 contains 13 additional SIMD instructions over SSE2. These instructions comprise five types.i. floating point to integer conversionii. complex arithmetic operationiii. video encodingiv. SIMD floating point operations using array of structures formatv. thread synchronization.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 10. The unit that may acts as an interface between the Front end and the Out of order execution engine in the pipeline flow is
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The micro-op queue acts as an interface between the Front end and the Out of order execution engine in the pipeline flow.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 11. The verification of the logic using formal mathematical tools is called
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The verification of the logic using formal mathematical tools is called formal verification.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 12. The formal verification is important for
options: c) to detect the bugs in design
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The formal verification is important to develop the tools and methodologies to handle a large number of proofs using which it will be possible to detect the bugs in the design.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 13. By using the techniques of formal verification, one can detect the logical bugs of
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: By using the techniques of formal verification, one can detect more than 100 logical bugs.

Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.question: 14. The modern processors are designed to achieve
options: b) operate at low operating voltage
Extended-Instruction-Set-In-Advanced-Pen.explaination: Explanation: The modern processors are designed to operate at a very high speed and even with the lower operating voltages, the power consumption is high enough to require expensive cooling technology.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 1. The disadvantage of CISC design processors is
options: a) low burden on compiler developers
b) wide availability of existing software
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: Some computers are used in preference to CISC design due to its low burden on compiler developers and wide availability of existing software. But they are complex in nature.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 2. The RISC architecture is preferred to CISC because RISC architecture has
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The RISC architecture is preferred to CISC because RISC architecture is simple, highly efficient and the processors using RISC architecture have high speed.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 3. The feature of RISC that is not present in CISC is
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: A RISC core allows performance enhancing features, such as branch prediction and pipelining. Traditionally, these have only been possible in RISC designs.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 4. The feature of hybrid CISC-RISC architecture is
options: a) consume a lot of power
b) not applicable to mobile applications
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The CISC-RISC hybrids continue to consume a lot of power and are not best candidates for mobile and embedded applications.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 5. Which of the following is an application of RISC architecture by adding more instructions?
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: By adding more instructions to the RISC architecture, some applications can be run much faster like multimedia applications, telecommunication encoding/decoding, image conversion and video processing.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 6. Which of the following processor belongs to hybrid RISC-CISC architecture?
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The processors, Intel Pentium III, Intel Itanium 64 and AMD’s X86-64 consists of hybrid RISC-CISC architecture.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 7. In order to implement complex instructions, CISC architectures use
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: In order to implement complex instructions, CISC architectures use microprogramming.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 8. The advantage of RISC processors is
options: a) can operate at high clock frequency
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The advantages of RISC processors are that they can work at high clock frequency, can be designed, developed and tested more quickly with a high speed.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 9. The additional functionality that can be placed on the same chip of RISC is
options: c) Memory management and floating point arithmetic units
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: Several extra functionalities, such as memory management units or floating point arithmetic units, can also be placed on the same chip of RISC.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 10. The number of clockcycles that take to wait until the length of the instruction is known in order to start decoding is
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The loading and decoding the instructions in a RISC processor is simple and fast. It is not needed to wait until the length of the instruction is known in order to start the decoding.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 1. The number of CPIs(Clock Per Instruction) for an instruction of RISC processors is
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: RISC processors have unity CPI(Clock Per Instruction), which is due to the optimization of each instruction on the CPU and massive pipelining embedded in a RISC processor.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 2. Which of the following is not true about RISC processors?
options: b) pipelining is key for high speed
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: Unlike the CISC, in RISC architecture, instruction microcoding is not required.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 3. The RISC processors that support variable length instructions are from
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: In RISC, each instruction is of the same length, so that it may be fetched in a single operation. The traditional microprocessors from Intel or Motorola support variable length instructions.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 4. Which of the following is true about register windowing?
options: a) chips expose 32 registers to programmer
c) puts enormous demands on register ports
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The register windowing involves a mechanism where the chips expose 32 registers to the programmer at any one time. It puts enormous demands on multiplexers and register ports to make any physical register appear to be any logical register.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 5. The disadvantage of register windowing is
options: b) puts demands on multiplexers/register ports
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: It is impossible to predict when the register file will overflow or underflow, so performance is unpredictable. It generates a software fault, which the operating system has to handle, consuming more cycles.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 6. The register window is used to point the number of physical registers is
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The register window only helps us to point the number of physical registers is finite.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 7. Which of the following is not a stage of pipeline of a RISC processor?
options: a) read registers and decode the instructions
c) write result into a register
d) access an operand in data memory
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: There are 5 stages in pipelining. They are1. Fetch instructions from memory2. Read registers and decode the instructions3. Execute the instructions or calculate an address4. Access an operand in data memory5. Write result into a register.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 8. When an instruction depends on the results of the previous instructions then
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: A data dependency occurs when an instruction depends on the results of the previous instructions.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 9. The instructions that instruct the processor to make a decision about the next instruction to be executed are
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: The branch instructions are those which instruct the processor to make a decision about the next instruction to be executed, depending upon whether the condition is satisfied or not.

Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.question: 10. The reason for which the RISC processor goes to idle state(or stall) is
options: a) delay in reading information from memory
Hybrid-Architecture--RISC-and-CISC-Conve.explaination: Explanation: There are a variety of reasons, including delays in reading information from memory, poor instruction set design, or dependencies between instructions for the RISC processor to remain idle.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 1. The register that may be used as an operand register is
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: In some instructions, the Accumulator and B register are used to store the operands.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 2. The register that can be used as a scratch pad is
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: B register is used to store one of the operands for multiply and divide instructions. In other instructions, it may just be used as a scratch pad.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 3. The registers that contain the status information is
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The set of flags of program status word contains the status information and is considered as one of the special function registers.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 4. Which of the processor’s stack does not contain the top-down data structure?
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The 8051 stack is not a top-down data structure, like other Intel processors.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 5. The architecture of 8051 consists of
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The architecture of 8051 consists of 4 latches and driver pairs are allotted to each of the four on-chip I/O ports. It contains two 16-bit timer registers.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 6. The transmit buffer of serial data buffer is a
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The transmit buffer of serial data buffer is a parallel-in serial-out register.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 7. The receive buffer of serial data buffer is a
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The serial data register has two buffers. The transmit buffer is a parallel-in serial-out register and receive buffer is a parallel-in serial-out register.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 8. The register that provides control and status information about counters is
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The registers, TMOD and TCON contain control and status information about timers/counters.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 9. The register that provides control and status information about serial port is
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The registers, PCON and SCON contain control and status information about serial port.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 10. The device that generates the basic timing clock signal for the operation of the circuit using crystal oscillator is
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The oscillator circuit generates the basic timing clock signal for the operation of the circuit using crystal oscillator.

Architecture-of-8051.question: 11. The registers that are not accessible by the user are
Architecture-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The arithmetic operations are performed over the operands held by the temporary registers, TMP1 and TMP2. Users cannot access these temporary registers.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 1. Which of the following is an 8-bit register?
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The registers, PSW, TCON and Accumulator are 8-bit registers.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 2. Which of the following register can be addressed as a byte?
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The registers, TMOD, SP, TH0, TH1, TL0, TL1 are to be addressed as bytes.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 3. Which of the following is bit-addressable register?
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The registers, accumulator, PSW, B, P0, P1, P2, P3, IP, IE, TCON and SCON are all bit-addressable registers.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 4. The higher and lower bytes of a 16-bit register DPTR are represented respectively as
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The registers, DPH and DPL are the higher and lower bytes of a 16-bit register DPTR.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 5. The register that is used for accessing external data memory is
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The Data Pointer(DPTR) is used for accessing external data memory which means that it includes both DPH and DPL.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 6. Among the four groups of register banks, the number of groups that can be accessed at a time is
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: At a time, only one of the four register banks can be accessed.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 7. The number of 8-bit registers that a register bank contain is
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The 32, 8-bit registers are divided into four groups of 8 registers each, called register banks.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 8. If RS1=1, RS0=0, then the register bank selected is
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: If RS1=1, RS0=0, then the register bank selected is register bank 2.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 9. If RS1=1, RS0=1, then the register bank selected is
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: If RS1=1, RS0=1, then the register bank selected is register bank 3. If RS1=0, RS0=0, then selected bank is register bank 0.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 10. The PCON register consists of
options: d) power down bit and idle bit
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The power control register, PCON consists of power down bit and idle bit which activate the power down mode and idle mode in 80C51BH.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 11. The on-chip oscillator is stopped in
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: In power down mode, the on-chip oscillator is stopped.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 12. In idle mode, the device that is disabled is
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: In idle mode, the oscillator continues to run and the interrupt, serial port and timer blocks are active but the clock to the CPU is disabled.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 13. The only way to terminate the power down mode is to
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The only way to terminate the power down mode is hardware reset. The reset redefines all the SFRs but the RAM contents are left unchanged.

Register-Set-of-8051.question: 14. The idle mode can be terminated by
Register-Set-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The idle mode can be terminated with a hardware interrupt or hardware reset signal.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 1. Which of the following is an external interrupt?
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: INT0(active low) and INT1(active low) are two external interrupt inputs provided by 8051.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 2. The interrupts, INT0(active low) and INT1(active low) are processed internally by flags
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The interrupts, INT0(active low) and INT1(active low) are processed internally by the flags IE0 and IE1.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 3. The flags IE0 and IE1, are automatically cleared after the control is transferred to respective vector if the interrupt is
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: If the interrupts are programmed as edge sensitive, the flags IE0 and IE1 are automatically cleared after the control is transferred to respective vector.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 4. If the external interrupt sources control the flags IE0 and IE1, then the interrupt programmed is
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: If the interrupts are programmed as level sensitive, then the flags IE0 and IE1 are controlled by external interrupt sources themselves.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 5. The pulses at T0 or T1 pin are counted in
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In counter mode, the pulses are counted at T0 or T1 pin.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 6. In timer mode, the oscillator clock is divided by a prescalar
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In timer mode, the oscillator clock is divided by a prescalar (1/32) and then given to the timer.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 7. The serial port interrupt is generated if
options: b) RI and TI are set
c) Either RI or TI is set
d) RI and TI are reset
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The serial port interrupt is generated if atleast one of the two bits, RI and TI is set.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 8. In serial port interrupt, after the control is transferred to the interrupt service routine, the flag that is cleared is
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In serial port interrupt, after the control is transferred to the interrupt service routine, neither of the flags are cleared.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 9. The atleast number of machine cycles for which the external interrupts that are programmed level-sensitive should remain high is
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The external interrupts, programmed level-sensitive should remain high for atleast 2 machine cycles.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.question: 10. If the external interrupts are programmed edge sensitive, then they should remain high for atleast
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: If the external interrupts are programmed edge sensitive, then they should remain high for atleast one machine cycle and low for atleast one machine cycle, for being sensed.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 1. The timer generates an interrupt, if the count value reaches to
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The timer is an up-counter and generates an interrupt when the count has reached FFFFH.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 2. The external interrupt that has the lowest priority among the following is
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The order of given interrupts from high to low priority is TF0, IE1 and TF1.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 3. Among the five interrupts generated by 8051, the lowest priority is given to the interrupt
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The interrupt, RI=TI (serial port) is given the lowest priority among all the interrupts.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 4. Among the five interrupts generated by 8051, the highest priority is given to the interrupt
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The interrupt, IE0(External INT0) is given the highest priority among all the interrupts.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 5. All the interrupts are enabled using a special function register called
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: All the interrupts are enabled using a special function register called interrupt enable register (IE) and their priorities are programmed using another special function register called interrupt priority register(IP).

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 6. The number of bytes stored on the stack during one operation of PUSH or POP is
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: As 8051 stack operations are 8-bit wide i.e. in an operation using PUSH or POP instruction, one byte of data is stored on a stack or retrieved from the stack. For implementing 16-bit operations, two 8-bit operations are cascaded.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 7. The step involved in PUSH operation is
options: a) increment stack by 2 and store 8-bit content to address pointed to by SP
b) decrement stack by 1 and store 16-bit content to address pointed to by SP
c) increment stack by 1 and store 8-bit content to address pointed to by SP
d) store 8-bit content to address pointed to by SP and then increment stack by 1
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The PUSH instruction follows two steps.1. Increment stack by 12. Store 8-bit content of the 8-bit address specified in the instruction to the address pointed to by SP.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 8. The step involved in POP operation is
options: a) decrement stack by 2 and store 8-bit content to address pointed to by SP
b) store 16-bit content to address pointed to by SP and decrement stack by 1
c) decrement stack by 1 and store content of top of stack to address pointed to by SP
d) store content of top of stack to address pointed to by SP and then decrement stack by 1
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The POP instruction follows two steps.1. Store the contents of top of stack pointed to by SP register to the 8-bit memory specified in the instruction.2. Decrement stack by 1.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 9. The 8051 stack is
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The 8051 stack is opposite to that in 8085 or 8086 i.e. in 8085 it is auto-decrement while in 8051 it is auto-increment during PUSH operations.

Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.question: 10. After reset, the stack pointer(SP) is initialized to the address of
Interrupt-and-Stack-of-8051-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The stack pointer(SP) is an 8-bit register and is initialized to internal RAM address 07H after reset.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 1. Which of the following is not an addressing mode of 8051?
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The six addressing modes of 8051 are1. Direct addressing2. Indirect addressing3. Register instructions4. Register specific(Register Implicit) instructions5. Immediate mode6. Indexed addressing.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 2. The symbol, ‘addr 16’ represents the 16-bit address which is used by the instructions to specify the
options: c) destination address of call or jump
d) source address of call or jump
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The symbol, ‘addr 16’ represents the 16-bit destination address which is used by the LCALL or LJMP instruction to specify the call or jump destination address, within 64 Kbytes program memory.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 3. The storage of addresses that can be directly accessed is
options: c) internal data RAM and SFRS
d) external data ROM and SFRS
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: Only internal data RAM and SFRS can be directly addressed in direct addressing mode.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 4. The address register for storing the 16-bit addresses can only be
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The address register for storing the 16-bit addresses can only be data pointer.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 5. The address register for storing the 8-bit addresses can be
options: a) R0 of the selected bank of register
b) R1 of the selected bank of register
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The registers R0 and R1 of the selected bank of registers or stack pointer can be used as address registers for storing the 8-bit addresses.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 6. The instruction, ADD A, R7 is an example of
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: In register instructions addressing mode, operands are stored in the registers R0-R7 of the selected register bank. One of these registers is specified in the instruction.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 7. The addressing mode, in which the instructions has no source and destination operands is
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: In register specific instructions addressing mode, the instructions don’t have source and destination operands. Some of the instructions always operate only on a specific register.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 8. The instruction, RLA performs
options: a) rotation of address register to left
b) rotation of accumulator to left
c) rotation of address register to right
d) rotation of accumulator to right
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The instruction, RLA rotates accumulator left.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 9. The instruction, ADD A, #100 performs
options: a) 100(decimal) is added to contents of address register
b) 100(decimal) is subtracted from the accumulator
c) 100(decimal) is added to contents of an accumulator
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: Immediate data 100(decimal) is added to the contents of the accumulator.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 10. In which of these addressing modes, a constant is specified in the instruction, after the opcode byte?
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: In immediate mode, an immediate data, i.e. a constant is specified in the instruction, after the opcode byte.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 11. The only memory which can be accessed using indexed addressing mode is
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: Only program memory can be accessed using the indexed addressing mode.

Addressing-Modes-of-8051.question: 12. The data address of look-up table is found by adding the contents of
options: a) accumulator with that of program counter
b) accumulator with that of program counter or data pointer
c) data register with that of program counter or accumulator
d) data register with that of program counter or data pointer
Addressing-Modes-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The look-up table data address is found out by adding the contents of register accumulator with that of the program counter or data pointer.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 1. Which of the following is not an instruction of 8051 instructions?
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The 8051 instructions are categorized as1. Data transfer instructions2. Arithmetic instructions3. Logical instructions4. Boolean instructions5. Control transfer instructions.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 2. The operations performed by data transfer instructions are on
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The data transfer instructions implement a bit, byte, 16-bit data transfer operations between the SRC(source) and DST(destination) operands.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 3. Which of the following is true while executing data transfer instructions?
options: a) program counter is not accessible
b) restricted bit-transfer operations are allowed
c) both operands can be direct/indirect register operands
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In data transfer instructions,1. Program counter is not accessible.2. Restricted bit-transfer operations are allowed.3. Both operands can be direct/indirect register operands.4. BOth operands can be internal direct data memory operands.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 4. The logical instruction that affects the carry flag during its execution is
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The logical instructions that doesn’t affect the carry flag are, ANL, ORL and XRL. The logical instructions that affect the carry flag during its execution are RL, RLC, RRC and RR.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 5. The instruction that is used to complement or invert the bit of a bit addressable SFR is
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The instruction, CPL Bit is used to complement or invert the bit of a bit addressable SFR or RAM.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 6. The instructions that change the sequence of execution are
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The control transfer instructions transfer the control of execution or change the sequence of execution conditionally or unconditionally.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 7. The control transfer instructions are divided into
options: a) explicit and implicit control transfer instructions
b) conditional and unconditional control transfer instructions
c) auto control and self control transfer instructions
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The control transfer instructions are divided into conditional and unconditional control transfer instructions.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 8. The conditional control transfer instructions check a bit condition which includes any bit of
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The conditional control transfer instructions check a bit condition which includes any bit of bit addressable RAM or bit addressable SFRs or content of accumulator for transferring the control to the specified jump location.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 9. All conditional jumps are
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: All conditional jumps are short jumps.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 10. The first byte of a short jump instruction represents
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The short jump instruction has two byte instruction. The first byte represents opcode byte and second byte represents an 8-bit relative address.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.question: 11. In logical instructions, the immediate data can be an operand for
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: In logical instructions, the immediate data can’t be an operand for increment/decrement or any other single operand instruction.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 1. If the most significant bit of relative address byte is 1, then the short jump instruction is
options: c) either forward or back jump
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If the most significant bit of relative address byte is 1, then the short jump instruction is back jump, else it is considered as forward jump.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 2. The first byte of an absolute jump instruction consists of
options: a) 3 LSBs of opcode and 5 MSBs of 11-bit address
b) 5 MSBs of opcode and 3 LSBs of 11-bit address
c) 6 MSBs of opcode and 1 LSB of 11-bit address
d) 5 LSBs of opcode and 3 MSBs of 11-bit address
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The first byte of an absolute jump instruction consists of 5 LSBs of opcode and 3 MSBs of 11-bit address. The next byte carries the least significant 8 bits of the 11-bit address.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 3. The third byte of the long jump instruction is
options: c) higher byte of jump location or subroutine
d) lower byte of jump location or subroutine
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The third byte of the long jump instruction is a higher byte of jump location or subroutine.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 4. The absolute jump instruction is intended mainly for a jump within a memory space of
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The absolute jump instruction is intended mainly for a jump within a memory space of 2 Kbytes.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 5. The LJMP instruction is very useful in programming in the external code memory space of
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The LJMP instruction is very useful in programming in the external code memory space of 64 KB.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 6. Which of the following is not an unconditional control transfer instruction?
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The instructions, JMP, RET, RETI, CALL are the unconditional control transfer instructions.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 7. The conditional control transfer instructions use
options: b) bits of bit addressable RAM
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The conditional control transfer instructions use status flags or bits of bit addressable RAM or SFRs termed bit.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 8. Which of the following is not a conditional control transfer instruction?
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The instructions, JC, JBC, JNC, JB and JNB are the conditional control transfer instructions.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 9. The mnemonic used to perform a subtraction of source with an 8-bit data and jumps to specified relative address if subtraction is non-zero is
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The CJNE instruction perform a subtraction of source with an 8-bit data and jumps to specified relative address only if the result of the subtraction is non-zero, else continues to the next instruction.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 10. The mnemonic, JNB is used to jump to the specified relative address only if
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The mnemonic, JNB is used to jump to the specified relative address only if specified bit=1, else continues to the next instruction.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 11. The type of operand that is not allowed to use in boolean instructions of 8051 is
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: In boolean instructions, the immediate bit is not allowed as an operand.

8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.question: 12. In boolean instructions, the flag that is the only allowed destination operand for two operand instructions is
8051-Instruction-Set-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: Carry flag(C) is the only allowed destination operand for two operand instructions in boolean instructions.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 1. Which of the following is not one of the SFR addresses of the ports of 8051?
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The SFR addresses of the ports P0, P1, P2 and P3 are 80H, 90H, A0H and B0H respectively.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 2. Each port line of a port can individually source a current of upto
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Each port line of a port can individually source a current of upto 0.5 mA.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 3. Each port line of a port can individually sink a current of upto
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Each port line of a port can individually sink a current of upto 8 mA.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 4. The number of TTL inputs that can be sinked by the port 0 when a logic 0 is sent to a port line as an output port is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: When a logic 0 is sent to a port line as an output port, it can sink 8 LS TTL inputs. Port 0 is used as data bus during external interfacing whenever required.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 5. The open drain bidirectional (input or output) port with internal pullups is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Port 0 is an open drain bidirectional (input or output) port with internal pullups. Port 1, Port 2, Port 3 are 8-bit bidirectional ports.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 6. The port that can source or sink 4 LS TTL inputs when being used as an output port on each of its line is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The ports P1, P2 and P3 can source or sink 4 LS TTL inputs when being used as an output port on each of its line.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 7. The port that will source a current of 500 micro amperes when being used as input ports is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Port 3 pins which are externally pulled low when being used as input pins will source current of 500 micro amperes.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 8. If the EA(active low) signal is grounded then the execution
options: a) directly start from main memory
b) directly start from 16 bit address in main memory
c) directly start from 16 bit address in program memory
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: For interfacing external program memory, EA(active low) pin must be grounded. If the EA(active low) signal is grounded then the execution will start directly from the 16-bit address 0000H in external program memory.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 9. When the port lines of a port are to be used as input lines then the value that must be written to the port address is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: When the port lines of a port are to be used as input lines then ‘FF’H must be written to the port address.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 10. Port 1 lines are used during programming of
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: Port 1 lines are used as lower byte of 16-bit address bus during programming of internal EPROM or EEPROM.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.question: 11. The configuration in which each LED receives operating current of 8 mA from power supply while the port lines sink the current on each port line is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-1.explaination: Explanation: The common anode configuration is preferred to that of other configurations as in common anode configuration, each LED receives operating current of 8 mA from power supply while the port lines sink the current on each port line.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 1. If EA(active low) signal =1, then the execution starts from
options: c) internal EPROM or flash RAM
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If EA(active low) signal =1, then the execution starts from an internal EPROM or flash RAM address 000H, can continue upto FFFH address and then for higher addresses it will go into external memory.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 2. The pin that is grounded for interfacing external EPROM is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The EA(active low) pin is grounded for interfacing external EPROM. The PSEN(active low) is used for interfacing EPROM i.e. it acts as an OE(active low) input to EPROM.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 3. The step that is involved in the procedure of memory interfacing with 8051 is
options: a) data bus is connected to data lines of memory chips
b) PSEN(active low) is connected to OE(active low) of EPROM chips
c) writing address map of memory chip in bit form
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The procedure of memory interfacing with 8051 includes, data bus connection to data lines of memory chips, PSEN(active low) connected to OE(active low) of EPROM chips and writing address map of memory chip in bit form.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 4. The device that is used for deriving chip select signals is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The logic gates and multiplexers are most commonly used for deriving chip select signals. The advanced circuits like PLAs and EPROMs are also used for deriving chip select signals.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 5. For deriving chip selects of isolated memory or IO devices, the gates that are traditionally used are
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: For deriving chip selects of isolated memory or IO devices, the NAND and NOT gates are traditionally used.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 6. The current that is required for a LED for an appropriate glow is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: For appropriate glow, a LED typically requires 8-10 mA with around 1.6 Volts.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 7. The maximum current that can be sinked totally by all the ports of 8051 is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: All the ports together (4 ports) should not be made to sink more than 71 mA.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 8. The number of LEDs that can be connected to a port of 8051, if all are expected to glow simultaneously is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: If 8 LEDs are connected to a port of 8051, and if all are expected to glow simultaneously, the total current sinked by the 8051 port will be 8×8=64 mA (since min voltage for an LED to glow=8 mA) which is less than the maximum 71 mA.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 9. Which is true in interfacing 7 segment code display?
options: b) display is selected by third port
c) display is selected by second port
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The 7-segment code of a digit is transmitted by the first port and the display is selected by second port. As soon as the display is selected by the second port, the digit starts glowing on that display position.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 10. After the display is selected by second port, then the digit (LED) glows for a duration of
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: The unit(LED) glows for a duration of 5 msec.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 11. The number of scans of the complete 8-digit display that can be carried out in one second is
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: Starting from either right most or left most digit, every digit glows for 5 msec one by one. Thus one scan of the 8 digit display requires 40 msec. Thus in one second, 25 scans of the complete 8-digit display can be carried out.

Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.question: 12. To convert its current output into a voltage, the DAC 0808 is connected with
Interfacing-With-8051-Ports-\u2013-2.explaination: Explanation: the DAC 0808 is connected with OPAMP externally, to convert its current output into voltage.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 1. The external interrupts of 8051 can be enabled by
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The external interrupts namely INT0(active low) and INT1(active low) can be enabled and programmed using the least significant four bits of TCON register and the Interrupt enable and priority registers.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 2. The bits that control the external interrupts are
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The bits, EX0 and EX1 individually control the external interrupts, INT0(active low) and INT1(active low). If INT0(active low) and INT1(active low) interrupts are to be enabled then the bits EX0 and EX1 must be set respectively.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 3. EA bit is used to
options: a) enable or disable external interrupts
b) enable or disable internal interrupts
c) enable or disable all the interrupts
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: Using EA bit, all the interrupts can be enabled or disabled. Using the individual respective bit, the respective interrupt can be enabled or disabled.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 4. The number of priority levels that each interrupt of 8051 have is
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: Each interrupts level of 8051 can have two levels of priority namely level 0 and level 1. Level 1 is considered as a higher priority level compared to level 0.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 5. The priority level of an interrupt of 8051 for which SI(serial interrupt) interrupt is programmed is
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: SI interrupt is programmed for level 1 priority.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 6. The interrupt bit that when set works at level 1, and otherwise at level 0 is
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The bits, PT1, PT0, PX0 and PX1 when set, work at level 1, otherwise at level 0.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 7. All the interrupts at level 1 are polled in the second clock cycle of the
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: All the interrupts at level 1 are polled or sensed in the second clock cycle of the fifth T state or 9th clock cycle out of 12 clock cycles. Then all the interrupts at level 0 are also polled in the same cycle.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 8. The minimum duration of the active low interrupt pulse for being sensed without being lost must be
options: a) greater than one machine cycle
b) equal to one machine cycle
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The minimum duration of the active low interrupt pulse should be equal to the duration of one machine cycle for being sensed, else it will be lost.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 9. If two interrupts, of higher priority and lower priority occur simultaneously, then the service provided is for
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: If two interrupts, occur simultaneously, then the one with higher priority level and early polling sequence will receive service. The other one with lower priority may get lost there, as there is no mechanism for storing the interrupt requests.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 10. For an interrupt to be guaranteed served it should have duration of
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: For an interrupt to be guaranteed served it should have duration of two machine cycles.

Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.question: 11. The service to an interrupt will be delayed if it appears during the execution of
options: b) Instruction that writes to IE register
c) Instruction that writes to IP register
Interrupt-Structure-of-8051.explaination: Explanation: The service to an interrupt will be delayed if it appears during the execution of RETI instruction or the instruction that writes to IE/IP registers.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 1. The serial communication is
options: b) requires less number of conductors
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: The serial communication requires less number of conductors and thus it is cheaper. It is slow as the bits are transmitted one by one along with start, stop and parity bits.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 2. The serial communication is used for
options: c) short and long distance communication
d) communication for a certain range of distance
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: Serial communication is more popular for communication over longer distances as it requires less number of conductors.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 3. The mcs 51 architecture supports
options: c) transmission and reception of data using serial communication interface
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: The mcs 51 architecture supports simultaneous transmission and reception of binary data byte by byte i.e. full duplex mode of communication. It supports serial transmission and reception of data using standard serial communication interface and baud rates.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 4. The number of bits transmitted or received per second is defined as
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: Here, baud rate can be defined as the number of bits transmitted or received per second.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 5. The task of converting the byte into serial form and transmitting it bit by bit along with start, stop and parity bits is carried out by
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: the serial communication unit consists of transmission unit and reception unit. The task of converting the byte into serial form and transmitting it bit by bit along with start, stop and parity bits is carried out by transmission unit.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 6. The transmission unit does not require assistance from processor if once a byte for transmission is written to
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: once a byte for transmission is written to the serial buffer(SBUF) register, the transmission unit does not require assistance from a processor.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 7. The common unit shared by the receiver unit and transmission unit of serial communication unit is
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: The transmission unit and receiver unit both are controlled by using a common SCON(Serial Port Control) Register. Also both units share a common serial buffer(SBUF) register which is a common 8-bit serial data interface.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 8. During serial reception, the buffer that receives serial bits and converts to a byte is
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: During serial reception, the receive buffer 1 receives serial bits and converts to a byte, it then transfers the received parallel byte in receive buffer 2.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 9. If SM0=1, SM1=0, then the transceiver selected is
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: If SM0=1, SM1=0, then the 9-bit asynchronous transceiver is selected.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 10. If the microcontroller is expected to communicate in a multiprocessor system, then the required condition is
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: The bit, SM2 is set if the microcontroller is expected to communicate in a multiprocessor system.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 11. In mode 2, the baud rate depends only on
options: d) SMOD bit and oscillator clock frequency
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: In mode 2, the baud rate depends only on SMOD bit and oscillator clock frequency.

Serial-Communication-Unit.question: 12. The mode that offers the most secured parity enabled data communication at lower baud rates is
Serial-Communication-Unit.explaination: Explanation: The mode 3 offers the most secured parity enabled data communication at lower baud rates of mode 1.

Power-Control-Register.question: 1. The power control register is
options: a) used for power saving during idle state
b) used for eventual power off to 8051 chip
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: The power control register is used for power saving during idle state of the microcontroller and eventual power off to the microcontroller chip. It has SMOD bit which is used to double the baud rate.

Power-Control-Register.question: 2. The state of signals in idle mode is
options: d) ALE and PSEN(active low) are high
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: ALE and PSEN(active low) remain high in Idle mode.

Power-Control-Register.question: 3. To come out of idle mode, the external interrupt that is enabled is
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: To come out of idle mode, any external interrupt that is enabled like SI(Serial), INT0 and INT1.

Power-Control-Register.question: 4. The microcontroller enters into power down mode when
options: a) SMOD bit of PCON is set
b) GF1 bit of PCON is set
c) PD bit of PCON is set
d) GF2 bit of PCON is set
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: If the PD bit of PCON register is set, it enters power down mode.

Power-Control-Register.question: 5. The clock signal is disabled to all parts of 8051 in
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: In power down mode, the clock signal to all parts of 8051 chip is disabled.

Power-Control-Register.question: 6. During power down to save battery, the supply voltage can be reduced to a value of
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: The supply voltage can be reduced to a value of around 2 volts, during power down to save battery.

Power-Control-Register.question: 7. The signal that only pulls the microcontroller(8051) out of the power down mode is
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: Only Reset signal can pull 8051 out of the power down mode.

Power-Control-Register.question: 8. The state of signals in power down mode is
options: c) ALE and PSEN(active low) are high
d) ALE and PSEN(active low) are low
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: ALE and PSEN(active low) remain low in power down mode of 8051.

Power-Control-Register.question: 9. In power down mode,
options: a) Port pins maintain their logic levels
b) SFRs maintain their logic levels
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: In power down mode, the clock signal is disabled and all the port pins and respective SFRs maintain their logic levels.

Power-Control-Register.question: 10. The SMOD bit is used to
options: a) decrease the baud rate by 2
b) increase the baud rate by 4
c) increase the baud rate by 2
Power-Control-Register.explaination: Explanation: The SMOD bit is used to double the baud rate.
